[[File:Sandstorm_of_Longjing_Township_,Taichung_County_in_Taiwan.jpg|thumb|right|A sandstorm hits [[Longjing, Taichung|Longjing]] Township, [[Taichung County]], in Taiwan on March 21, 2010.]]
The '''2010 China drought and dust storms''' were a series of severe [[drought]]s during the spring of 2010 that affected [[Yunnan]], [[Guizhou]], [[Guangxi]], [[Sichuan]], [[Shanxi]], [[Henan]], [[Shaanxi]], [[Chongqing]], [[Hebei]] and [[Gansu]] in the [[People's Republic of China]] as well as parts of [[Southeast Asia]] including [[Vietnam]] and [[Thailand]], and [[dust storm]]s in March and April that affected much of [[East Asia]]. The drought has been referred to as the worst in a century in southwestern China.<ref name="Asiait">Asianews.it. "[http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Worst-drought-in-a-century-wipes-out-harvests-in-southwestern-China-17947.html Asianews.it]." ''Worst drought in a century wipes out harvests in southwestern China.'' Retrieved on 2010-03-22.</ref>
==Causes== Prior to the drought in Yunnan and Guizhou, the [[China Meteorological Administration]] recorded temperatures averaging 2 °C warmer than normal over six months and half the average precipitation for the past year across the region, both unprecedented since at least the 1950s.<ref name="guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/mar/25/china-drought-emergency-food|title=China sends emergency food to drought-stricken provinces|last=Watts|first=Jonathan|date=March 25, 2010|work=Guardian News and Media Limited|publisher=guardian.co.uk|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100328031753/http://www.guardian.co.uk/environment/2010/mar/25/china-drought-emergency-food| archivedate=March 28, 2010<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The effects of [[El Niño]] are believed to be contributing to the drought, which may be exacerbated by [[global warming]],<ref name="Forbes">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/04/08/china-water-drought-control-opinions-columnists-gordon-g-chang.html |title=Will China Run Out Of Water? |last=Chang |first=Gordon G. |date=April 9, 2010 |publisher=Forbes.com |accessdate=16 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412071422/http://www.forbes.com/2010/04/08/china-water-drought-control-opinions-columnists-gordon-g-chang.html |archivedate=12 April 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> as some areas in Yunnan have recorded record high temperatures during the winter since record-keeping began in 1950.<ref name="bjreview">{{cite news|url=http://www.bjreview.com.cn/nation/txt/2010-03/29/content_258734.htm|title=Drought Takes its Toll|last=Liu|first=Yunyun|date=April 1, 2010|publisher=Beijing Review|accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref> Some areas in the drought-affected regions have seen no rainfall since before October.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/05/world/asia/05china.html?src=me|title=Spring Harvest of Debt for Parched Farms in Southern China|last=Wangzhi Journal|first=Asia Pacific|date=April 4, 2010|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=11 April 2010}}</ref> Spring dust storms are common in China, but have become more severe in recent years due to [[desertification]], [[deforestation]], [[drought]], [[urban sprawl]] and [[overgrazing]].<ref name="AP">{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jRAywP2HiPafKiAikGO_jlpPj0GwD9EK0DR00|title=China's sandstorms blast Beijing with dust, sand|last=Bodeen|first=Christopher|date=March 22, 2010|publisher=The Associated Press|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100326193623/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jRAywP2HiPafKiAikGO_jlpPj0GwD9EK0DR00| archivedate= 26 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Countries downstream from Yunnan are also affected by drought conditions upriver, and some places including much of Vietnam have seen very little precipitation since the previous September.<ref name="Timeoverland">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1969630,00.html?iid=sphere-inline-sidebar|title=Vietnam Feels the Heat of a 100-Year Drought|last=Overland|first=Martha Ann|date=March 4, 2010|work=Time Inc|publisher=TIME.com|accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref>
A severe drought in 2009 also affected much of [[North China|Northern China]] and [[Northeastern China]], resulting in agricultural losses of up to 50%.<ref name="bjreview"/>
==Water shortages== By March 22, 2010, about 51 million people faced [[water shortages]] in a number of provinces.<ref name="Asiait" /> Commodities including [[sugar cane]], [[flower]]s, [[tea]], [[fruit]], [[potato]]es, [[rapeseed]], [[traditional Chinese medicine|medicinal ingredients]], [[tobacco]], [[wheat]],<ref name="Chinadaily">{{cite news|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2010-04/09/content_9705016.htm|title=Dry spell hits where it hurts|last=Wang|first=Huazhong|author2=Peng Yining, Li Yingqing|date=April 9, 2010|publisher=China Daily|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100413132021/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2010-04/09/content_9705016.htm| archivedate= 13 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[rubber]] and [[coffee]] have been severely affected with output reduced by as much as 50%. Authorities began to fear unrest due to soaring food prices<ref name="Forbes"/> and sent more than 10,000 [[Chinese People's Armed Police Force|armed police]] to the affected regions to ensure stability and help with water supplies.<ref name="Asiait" /> More than 20 million people<ref name="NTDTV">{{cite news|url=http://english.ntdtv.com/ntdtv_en/ns_china/2010-04-15/064280183637.html|title=China's Hydropower May Be Worsening Drought|last=China|first=NTDTV|date=April 15, 2010|publisher=New Tang Dynasty Television|accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref> are left without adequate drinking water in Yunnan, Guangxi, Guizhou, Sichuan and Chongqing, and many [[Water well|well]]s in Yunnan have gone dry. The three wells in the village of [[Xiazha]] in Guangxi Autonomous Region were reported to have gone completely dry for the first time since 1517, in addition to three [[reservoir]]s in the area going dry.<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/7527348/Southern-China-suffers-worst-drought-in-memory.html|title=Southern China suffers worst drought in memory|last=Moore|first=Malcolm|date=March 26, 2010|work=Telegraph Media Group Limited|publisher=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100330074807/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/7527348/Southern-China-suffers-worst-drought-in-memory.html| archivedate= 30 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Economic damage to agriculture and failed [[electricity generation]] from [[hydroelectric dam]]s<ref name="Telegraph"/> from the drought was estimated to be at least 24 billion [[Chinese yuan]] ([[US dollar|$]]3.5 billion USD). Around 3,600 rivers and [[Stream|brooks]] in Guizhou have run dry, while 916,000 [[hectare|ha]] of crops were affected by drought in the province and one million farmers have left to find work in other provinces. The drought affected over 28 million farmers, and a [[grain]] shortage has affected 8 million people. The [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese government]] has transferred 1.7 million tonnes of grain to the region to reduce potential [[inflation]].<ref name="Chinadaily"/> About 4.348 million ha of cropland were affected by the drought in Southwestern China and 942,000 ha would yield no harvest by late March, according to China's State Commission of Disaster Relief.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0322/1224266810808.html|title=More than 50 million hit by drought in south of China|last=Coonan|first=Clifford|date=March 22, 2010|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=11 April 2010}}</ref> In late March, the government began [[cloud seeding]] in Guizhou using [[silver iodide]] to produce rain.<ref name="Telegraph"/> By April 10, the drought had eased in Chongqing due to heavy rain, but it had affected over 18 million [[livestock]] and 8.13 million ha of land.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-04/10/c_13245644.htm|title=Drought eases in Chongqing, lingers in other affected regions|last=Xinhua|first=English.news.cn|date=April 10, 2010|work=Xinhua News Agency|publisher=English.news.cn|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418030416/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-04/10/c_13245644.htm| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In parts of Yunnan Province inhabited by the [[Dai people]], officials cancelled or shortened the [[Songkran (disambiguation)|Songkran]] water [[dousing]] festival due to the water shortage, including in [[Dehong Dai and Jingpo Autonomous Prefecture]] and [[Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1981220,00.html?xid=rss-topstories|title=Drought Throws Cold Water on Yunnan's Water Festival|last=Brenhouse|first=Hillary|date=April 13, 2010|work=TIME Inc|publisher=TIME.com|accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref> By early June, the drought had affected close to 5 million hectares of land.<ref name="GoogleAP">{{cite news|last=Google News|first=AP|title=Landslides, flooding kill 53 in southern China|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hHfFBvX2yQ_i_xgymQAV_XTotGHQD9G69BJ80|accessdate=1 July 2010|newspaper=The Associated Press|date=June 6, 2010}}</ref>
The drought may also affect water levels at the headwaters of the [[Yangtze River|Chang Jiang]], [[Mekong River|Mekong]] and [[Salween River]]s.<ref name="guardian"/> Some experts believe that [[hydropower]] production may be contributing to the water shortage from the drought.<ref name="NTDTV"/> Countries downstream of the Mekong, including [[Thailand]], suggested that the building of [[dam]]s on the river such as at [[Lancang River|Lancang]] may be worsening the effects of drought on the river's water levels,<ref name="NYT"/> which were at their lowest in 20 years.<ref name="Telegraph"/> Fisheries along the Mekong in Thailand have halted, and 7.9 million people in the country are affected by the drought. 3,674 small dams within the river basin have dried up.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/04/06/china.mekong.river.thailand.laos/|title=Drought grips parts of China, Southeast Asia amid dam concerns|last=Leitsinger|first=Miranda|date=April 7, 2010|work=Turner Broadcasting System|publisher=Cable News Network|accessdate=17 April 2010|location=Hong Kong| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100412011928/http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/04/06/china.mekong.river.thailand.laos/| archivedate= 12 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The drought in Vietnam was described as the country's worst in a century. The [[Red River (Asia)|Red River]] near [[Hanoi]] was by early March at a level of {{convert|0.68|m|ft|abbr=on}}, the lowest on record, and [[rice]] plantations have been severely affected. [[Forest fire|Timber fire]]s have been sparked in several regions. The [[Mekong Delta]] experienced its lowest water levels in nearly 20 years, threatening to produce [[saltwater intrusion]] in dry areas. Some parts of Vietnam are forecast to possibly receive no rain until August.<ref name="Timeoverland"/> A power shortage of up to one billion [[kilowatt-hour]]s could also hit the country as less water is available for hydroelectricity.<ref name="Nguyen">{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-04-06/vietnam-faces-power-shortage-as-drought-hurts-hydroelectricity.html|title=Vietnam Faces Power Shortage as Drought Hurts Hydroelectricity|last=Nguyen|first=Dieu Tu Uyen|date=April 6, 2010|work=Bloomberg|publisher=Business Week|accessdate=16 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100414102530/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-04-06/vietnam-faces-power-shortage-as-drought-hurts-hydroelectricity.html| archivedate= 14 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The El Niño conditions of the winter prior to the drought has raised concerns that the rice crop in Vietnam, Thailand and the [[Philippines]] may be significantly reduced by the summer.<ref name="Nguyen"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-04-07/rice-output-may-drop-in-thailand-on-drought-fao-says-update1-.html|title=Rice Output May Drop in Thailand on Drought, FAO Says (Update2)|last=Suwannakij|first=Supunnabul|author2=Luzi Ann Javier|date=April 7, 2010|work=Bloomberg|publisher=Business Week|accessdate=17 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100421044252/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-04-07/rice-output-may-drop-in-thailand-on-drought-fao-says-update1-.html| archivedate= 21 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The lack of precipitation caused [[land subsidence]] at [[Kunming Wujiaba International Airport]] in Yunnan.<ref name="bjreview"/>
About 5,000 villagers in Yunnan Province have left their homes from the drought for streams near [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] [[foothill]]s,<ref name="Telegraph"/> and many residents in Guangxi who are able to leave have also left. However, officials have denied reports of [[climate refugee|drought refugee]]s leaving their villages.<ref name="Forbes"/> The source of the [[Pearl River (China)|Pearl River]]'s [[headwaters]] was cut off, and its outflow was severely reduced. [[Water rationing]] was put into practice in some rural regions.<ref name="bjreview"/>
Shortages of drinking water also affected parts of [[Inner Mongolia]], including a water shortage for over 250,000 residents of [[Chifeng]]. Reservoirs in the city held 73.7% less water than they did one year prior and water volume had reduced by 77.4% in major rivers in the area by mid-April.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-04/10/c_13245689.htm|title=Drought affects 250,000 people in Chifeng of Inner Mongolia|last=Xinhua|first=English.news.cn|date=April 10, 2010|work=Xinhua News Agency|publisher=English.news.cn|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418030419/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-04/10/c_13245689.htm| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The drought has affected [[non-ferrous metal]] production in Guangxi, including of [[electrolytic]] [[zinc]], with companies in [[Nandan County]] cutting production by 30%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/bizchina/2010-04/10/content_9712227.htm|title=Lingering drought threatens SW China non-ferrous metal production|last=Xinhua|first=China Daily|date=April 10, 2010|publisher=China Daily|accessdate=16 April 2010|location=Nanning| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100417022907/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/bizchina/2010-04/10/content_9712227.htm| archivedate= 17 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Chinese Premier]] [[Wen Jiabao]] visited southwestern China three times during the drought, including a three-day tour in mid-March in Yunnan, including [[Luliang County]], which had seen no rainfall since August, to promote [[water conservation]],<ref name="NYT"/> and another visit in early April 2010 to several [[Miao people|Miao]] and [[Buyei]] [[Autonomous Prefecture]]s in Guizhou, some of the worst-hit places where farming has been made impossible.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2010drought/2010-04/05/content_9687187.htm|title=Premier concerned about drought in SW China|last=Xinhua|first=China Daily|date=April 5, 2010|work=Xinhua|publisher=China Daily|accessdate=11 April 2010|location=Guiyang}}</ref>
Most provinces in South China affected by the drought were hit by a [[2010 South China floods|series of floods]] beginning in mid-May that ended most of the drought but also destroyed large areas of farmland.<ref name="GoogleAP"/><ref>{{cite news|last=English.news.cn|first=Xinhua|title=Strong rain to continue in flood-hit southern China|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-05/21/c_13307917.htm|accessdate=1 July 2010|newspaper=Xinhuanet|date=May 21, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100608024004/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-05/21/c_13307917.htm| archivedate= 8 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Dust storms== {{see also|Asian Dust}} Strong dust storms from the [[Gobi Desert]] in [[Mongolia]] hit [[Xinjiang Autonomous Region]], [[Inner Mongolia]], [[Shaanxi]], [[Shanxi]], [[Hebei]], [[Beijing]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Taiwan]], [[South Korea]], [[North Korea]] and [[Japan]] by March 22, before being carried across the [[Pacific Ocean]] by the [[jet stream]], with some dust reaching the [[West Coast of the United States]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article7070109.ece|title=Beijing turned orange as sandstorm sweeps in|last=Online|first=Times|date=March 21, 2010|work=Times Newspapers Ltd|publisher=Times Online|accessdate=11 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_505838.html|title=Dust settles in Beijing|last=Breaking News|first=The Straits Times|author2=Associated Press|date=March 24, 2010|work=Bloomberg|publisher=The Straits Times|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100328124351/http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_505838.html| archivedate= 28 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/view.php?id=43207|title=Spring Sandstorm Scours China|last=Terra|first=MODIS|author2=Rebecca Lindsey|date=March 20, 2010|work=Earth Observatory|publisher=National Aeronautics and Space Administration|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428080134/http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/view.php?id=43207| archivedate= 28 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The dust storm in late March spiralled around a strong [[low pressure]] system.<ref name="Earthweek">{{cite web|url=http://www.earthweek.com/2010/ew100326/ew100326x.html|title=Sino Sandstorm: Earth Image of the Week|last=NASA|first=EarthWeek|date=March 26, 2010|work=MMIX Earth Environment Service|publisher=EarthWeek|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100329161151/http://www.earthweek.com/2010/ew100326/ew100326x.html| archivedate= 29 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Many areas recorded an extremely rare level 5 "hazardous" rating for [[air quality]].<ref name="AP"/> Many flights in Beijing were also delayed or cancelled.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/20/beijing-sandstorm-2010-ph_n_506875.html|title=Beijing Sandstorm 2010: PHOTOS Of Major China Storm|last=AP|first=Huffington Post|date=March 20, 2010|work=The Associated Press|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100326044259/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/20/beijing-sandstorm-2010-ph_n_506875.html| archivedate= 26 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Air pollution readings in Hong Kong reached a record high, reaching at least 15 times the recommended maximum levels by the [[World Health Organization]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article7072220.ece|title=Hong Kong disappears in cloud of smog|last=Macartney|first=Jane|date=March 23, 2010|publisher=Times Online|accessdate=11 April 2010}}</ref> Taiwan also reported a new record for worst sandstorm conditions.<ref name="Earthweek"/>
A strong sandstorm tore through [[Turpan]] in Xinjiang on April 23, sparking fires that killed two people and forcing a shutdown of rail and road traffic for six hours.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3&stormfile=chinasand_aprtwentyfour_24_04_2010?ref=ccbox_weather_bottom_title |title=Weather News: Extreme Weather Battles China |last=Weather News |first=The Weather Network |date=April 24, 2010 |work=Pelmorex Media Inc |publisher=The Weather Network |accessdate=24 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100427034803/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3Dchinasand_aprtwentyfour_24_04_2010?ref=ccbox_weather_bottom_title |archivedate=27 April 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==Relief== [[Oxfam Hong Kong]] provided water in Yunnan.<ref name="reliefw">Reliefweb.int. "[http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/NMUO-836TBX?OpenDocument Reliefweb.int]." ''Oxfam provides water in China’s worst drought in decades: 10 Million people short of drinking water.'' Retrieved on 2010-03-18.</ref> A major fundraiser was also held that raised 280 million [[Chinese yuan|yuan]]. Many celebrities took part including Wang Feng (汪峰), [[Elva Hsiao]], [[Andy Lau]], [[He Jie]], [[Jackie Chan]], Ye bei (叶蓓), Yan Wei-wen (阎维文), Zhou Xiao-ou (周晓欧), [[Bibi Zhou]], and Yang-zi (杨紫).<ref>Bayuq.cn. "[http://www.bayuq.cn/n148769c22.aspx Bayuq.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100414035618/http://www.bayuq.cn/n148769c22.aspx |date=2010-04-14 }}." ''《抗旱救灾 我们在行动》公益晚会募捐善款近2.8亿.'' Retrieved on 2010-04-06.</ref><ref>Ent.qq.com. "[http://ent.qq.com/zt2010/2010zhenzai/index.htm Ent.qq.com]." ''Relief main site.'' Retrieved on 2010-04-06.</ref> The [[Hong Kong government]] also approved a [[HK$]]1.4 million grant.<ref>Chinahumanrights.org. "[http://www.chinahumanrights.org/Messages/feature/29/t20100326_564314.htm Chinahumanrights.org]." ''HK approves grant to help drought victims in Chinese Mainland.'' Retrieved on 2010-04-06.</ref>
Many donations of [[bottled water]] have also arrived in Guizhou and other parts of southwestern China from around the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/photo/2010-04/10/c_13245603.htm|title=More drought relief donations come to SW China|last=Xinhua|first=English.news.cn|author2=Wang Guanqun|date=April 10, 2010|work=Xinhua News Agency|publisher=English.news.cn|accessdate=11 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418030610/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/photo/2010-04/10/c_13245603.htm| archivedate= 18 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Algal blooms== In mid-June 2010, a large [[algal bloom]], consisting of ''[[enteromorpha]]'' algae, developed off the coast of [[Shandong]], in the [[Yellow Sea]]. Causes of the algal outbreak include [[marine pollution]] from [[sewage]] and [[agriculture in China|agricultural]] [[Surface runoff|run-off]], in addition to run-off from [[fish farm]]s, worsened by [[eutrophication]] following the drought, subsequent flooding and heat wave, as well as high [[sea surface temperature]]s in the area. The bloom continues to expand, and preparations have been made for a flotilla of vessels to ward off the bloom, covering an area of {{convert|400|sqkm|sqmi|abbr=on}}, the largest bloom since 2008.<ref>{{cite news|last=AP|first=Google|title=Big algae bloom expanding off China's east coast|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5i1iqc1fa1dBy0ZV-_wdnSn0JqtRgD9GI6T081|accessdate=15 July 2010|newspaper=The Associated Press|date=June 25, 2010}}</ref> The patch of algae since expanded offshore [[Jiangsu]] Province, and is pushing toward the city of [[Qingdao]]. The Chinese [[State Oceanic Administration]] has warned that the algae could threaten [[marine life]] and local tourism,<ref>{{cite news|last=AFP|first=Google|title=Giant China algae slick getting bigger: report|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hSiWseNyLK_RtJsP8_En0NkIq8kQ|accessdate=15 July 2010|newspaper=Agence France-Presse|date=June 23, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630075735/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hSiWseNyLK_RtJsP8_En0NkIq8kQ| archivedate= 30 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and other scientists have stated that the bloom could decompose on beaches and release toxic gases if not cleaned up. Close to 4,000 tonnes a day of algae is being removed from the bloom, to be sent off and used as [[Fodder|animal feed]] or [[fertilizer]]. Green and [[red tide]]s have become more common in China in recent years. The green tides from the current algal blooms can also result in [[dead zone (ecology)|dead zone]]s from localized [[ocean anoxia]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Watts|first=Jonathan|title=China launches armada to head off algae plume|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/07/china-algae|accessdate=15 July 2010|newspaper=guardian.co.uk|date=7 July 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100710194139/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/jul/07/china-algae| archivedate= 10 July 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Large blooms of [[jellyfish]], including giant [[Nomura's jellyfish]] have also appeared off Shandong and around the coasts of Japan within the past decade, as a result of the same type of pollution in dead zones.

{{about| advanced materials and their applications| the scientific journal| Advanced Composite Materials (journal)}} '''Advanced composite materials''' (ACMs) are also known as '''advanced polymer matrix composites'''. These are generally characterized or determined by unusually high strength fibres with unusually high [[stiffness]], or [[modulus of elasticity]] characteristics, compared to other materials, while bound together by weaker matrices. These are termed advanced composite materials (ACM) in comparison to the [[composite material]]s commonly in use such as [[reinforced concrete]], or even concrete itself. The [[Composite laminates|high strength fibers]] are also low [[density]] while occupying a large fraction of the [[volume]]
Advanced composites exhibit desirable [[physical properties|physical]] and [[chemical properties]] that include light weight coupled with high stiffness ([[elasticity (physics)|elasticity]]), and strength along the direction of the reinforcing fiber, dimensional stability, temperature and chemical resistance, [[Flexible response|flex performance]], and relatively easy processing. Advanced composites are replacing metal components in many uses, particularly in the [[aerospace industry]].
Composites are classified according to their [[states of matter|matrix phase]]. These classifications are polymer matrix composites (PMCs), [[Ceramic Matrix Composite|ceramic matrix composite]]s (CMCs), and [[metal matrix composite]]s (MMCs). Also, materials within these categories are often called "advanced" if they combine the properties of high (axial, [[longitude|longitudinal]]) strength values and high ([[Geometry|axial]], longitudinal) stiffness values, with low weight, corrosion resistance, and in some cases special [[electrical]] properties.
Advanced composite materials have broad, proven applications, in the [[aircraft]], aerospace, and [[sports equipment]] sectors. Even more specifically ACMs are very attractive for aircraft and aerospace structural parts. ACMs have been developing for NASA's ''[[Advanced Space Transportation Program]]'', armor protection for ''[[Army aviation]]'' and the ''[[Federal Aviation Administration]]'' of the USA, and high-temperature shafting for the ''[[Comanche helicopter]]''. Additionally, ACMs have a decades long history in military and government [[aerospace industry|aerospace industries]]. However, much of the technology is new and not presented formally in secondary or [[undergraduate education]], and the technology of advanced composites manufacture is continually evolving.<ref name=Pilato-Michno> {{Cite book | last = Pilato | first =L. |author2=Michno, Michael J. | title =Advanced composite materials| publisher =Springer-Verlag New York| date =January 1994 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=O379nM3QZwsC&dq=Advanced+Composite+Materials | format =Chap 1 Introduction, and Chapter 2 "Matrix Resins"| isbn =978-3-540-57563-4 }}</ref><ref name=OSHA-ACM/><ref name=ACM-group/> :{{OSHA}} :{{Include-NASA}}
==Overview and historical perspective== Manufacturing ACMs is a multibillion-dollar industry worldwide. Composite products range from [[skateboard]]s to components of the [[space shuttle]]. The industry can be generally divided into two basic segments, industrial composites and advanced composites. Several of the composites manufacturing processes are common to both segments. The two basic segments are described below.<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM/>
===Industrial composites=== The industrial composites industry has been in place for over 40 years in the U.S. This large industry utilizes various [[resin]] systems including [[polyester]], [[epoxy]], and other specialty resins. These materials, along with a [[catalyst]] or [[curing agent]] and some type of fiber reinforcement (typically glass fibers) are used in the production of a wide spectrum of industrial components and consumer goods: boats, piping, auto bodies, and a variety of other parts and components.<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM/>
===Advanced composites=== The Advanced polymer matrix composites industry, or Advanced composite materials industry, is characterized by the use of expensive, high-performance resin systems and high-strength, high-stiffness fiber reinforcement. The aerospace industry, including [[military aircraft|military]] and [[commercial aircraft]] of all types, is the major customer for advanced composites. These materials have also been adopted for use by the [[sporting goods]] suppliers who sell [[high-performance equipment]] to the [[golf]], [[tennis]], [[fishing]], and [[archery]] markets;<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM/><ref name=ACM-group/> as well as in the swimming pool industry with Composite wall structures.<ref>http://www.onlyalpha.com</ref>
While aerospace is the predominant market for advanced composites today, the industrial and [[automotive market]]s will increasingly see the use of advanced composites toward the year 2000(Its now 2017 this is out of date). At present, both manual and automated processes are employed in making advanced-composite parts. As automated processes become more predominant, the costs of advanced composites are expected to decline to the point at which these materials will be used widely in electronic, machinery, and surface transportation equipment.
Suppliers of advanced composite materials tend to be larger companies capable of doing the [[research and development]] necessary to provide the high-performance resin systems used in this segment of the industry. End-users also tend to be large, and many are in the aircraft and aerospace businesses.<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM/><ref name=ACM-group/>
===Design Guidelines for composite materials=== To achieve your desired characteristics like good strength, wear resistance, good impact resistance, rigidity, toughness, good weather resistance etc. you may follow these guidelines.
"Align the fibers with the load's direction."
"Avoid shear loading."
"Combine several components into an integral structure."
"Use light core material covered with strong composite layer."
"Avoid high temperatures."
"Involve manufacturing considerations early in the design."
==Matrix Materials== Advanced composite systems are divided into two basic types based on the chemical characteristics of the matrix, the two most common are thermosets and thermoplastics. Thermosets are by far the predominant type in use today. Thermosets are subdivided into several resin systems including epoxies, phenolics, polyurethanes, and polyimides. Of these, epoxy systems currently dominate the advanced composite industry.<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM/><ref name=ACM-group/>
===Thermosets=== [[Thermoset]] resins require addition of a [[curing agent]] or hardener and impregnation onto a reinforcing material, followed by a [[curing agent|curing step]] to produce a cured or finished part. Once cured, the part cannot be changed or reformed, except for finishing. Some of the more common thermosets include [[epoxy]], [[polyurethane]]s, phenolic and amino resins, [[bismaleimide]]s (BMI, polyimides), [[polyamide]]s.<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM/><ref name=ACM-group/>
Of these, epoxies are the most commonly used in the industry. Epoxy resins have been in use in U.S. industry for over 40 years. Epoxy compounds are also referred to as glycidyl compounds. The epoxy molecule can also be expanded or cross-linked with other molecules to form a wide variety of resin products, each with distinct performance characteristics. These resins range from low-viscosity liquids to high-molecular weight solids. Typically they are high-viscosity liquids.
The second of the essential ingredients of an advanced composite system is the curing agent or hardener. These compounds are very important because they control the reaction rate and determine the performance characteristics of the finished part. Since these compounds act as catalysts for the reaction, they must contain active sites on their molecules. Some of the most commonly used curing agents in the advanced composite industry are the aromatic amines. Two of the most common are methylene-dianiline (MDA) and sulfonyldianiline (DDS).
Several other types of curing agents are also used in the advanced composite industry. These include aliphatic and cycloaliphatic amines, polyaminoamides, amides, and anhydrides. Again, the choice of curing agent depends on the cure and performance characteristics desired for the finished part. Polyurethanes are another group of resins used in advanced composite processes. These compounds are formed by reacting the [[polyol]] component with an isocyanate compound, typically [[toluene diisocyanate]] (TDI); [[methylene diisocyanate]] (MDI) and [[hexamethylene diisocyanate]] (HDI) are also widely used. Phenolic and amino resins are another group of PMC resins. The bismaleimides and polyamides are relative newcomers to the advanced composite industry and have not been studied to the extent of the other resins.<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM/><ref name=ACM-group/>
===Thermoplastics=== [[Thermoplastic]]s currently represent a relatively small part of the ACM industry. They are typically supplied as nonreactive solids (no [[chemical reaction]] occurs during processing) and require only [[thermodynamics|heat and pressure]] to form the finished part. Unlike the thermosets, the thermoplastics can usually be reheated and reformed into another shape, if desired.<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM/><ref name=ACM-group/>
==Fiber reinforcements== Fiber reinforcement materials are added to the resin system increase the tensile strength and stiffness of the finished part. The selection of reinforcement material is based on the properties desired in the finished product. These materials do not react with the resin but are a distinct and integral part of the advanced composite system.
The three basic types of fiber reinforcement materials in use in the advanced composite industry are
* carbon ([[Carbon (fibre)]], [[graphite]], [[carbon nanotube]]s) * [[aramid]] * [[glass fiber]]s
Fibers used in advanced composite manufacture come in various forms, including tows, yarns, rovings, chopped strands, and woven fabric mats. Each of these has its own special application. When prepreg materials are used in parts manufacture, woven fabric or mats are required. In processes such as filament wet winding or pultrusion, yarns and rovings are used.<ref name=OSHA-ACM/><ref name=ACM-group/>
==Prepreg== Prepregs are resin-impregnated cloth, mat, or filaments in flat form that can be stored for later use. The resin is often partially cured to a tack-free state called "B-staging." Catalysts, inhibitors, flame retardants, and other additives may be included to obtain specific end-use properties and improve processing, storage, and handling characteristics.<ref name=Pilato-Michno/><ref name=OSHA-ACM>{{cite web | last =OSHA | title =Polymer Matrix Materials: Advanced Composites | publisher =U.S. Department of Labor | date =May 4, 2009 | url =http://www.osha.gov/dts/osta/otm/otm_iii/otm_iii_1.html#1 | accessdate =2010-06-05| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100528112048/http://www.osha.gov/dts/osta/otm/otm_iii/otm_iii_1.html| archivedate= 28 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} Public domain content from a U.S. government department. [http://www.dol.gov/dol/aboutdol/copyright.htm Materials created by the federal government] are generally part of the public domain and may be used, reproduced and distributed without permission.</ref><ref name=ACM-group> {{cite web |last =ACG | title =Introduction to Advanced Composites and Prepreg Technology | publisher =Advanced Composites Group | date =2006 | url =http://www.advanced-composites.co.uk/data_catalogue/catalogue%20files/sm/SM1010-INTRO%20TO%20ADV%20COMPS-Rev06.pdf | format =free PDF download | accessdate =2010-06-05}}</ref>
==Limitations== Despite their strength and low weight, composites have not been a miracle solution for aircraft structures. Composites are typically difficult to inspect for flaws. Some of them absorb moisture. Most importantly, they can be prohibitively expensive, primarily because they are labor-intensive and often require complex and expensive fabrication machines. Aluminium, by contrast, is easy and inexpensive to manufacture and repair, for example in a minor collision an aluminium component can often be hammered back into its original shape, whereas a crunched fiberglass component will likely have to be completely replaced.<ref name="CentComm">{{cite web| last =Day| first =Dwayne A.| title =Composites and Advanced Materials| publisher =NASA. U.S. Centennial of Flight Commission.| year =2003| url =http://www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Evolution_of_Technology/composites/Tech40.htm| format =Centennial of Flight Commemoration Act Public Law 105-389 105th Congress (November 13, 1998)| accessdate =2010-06-05| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20100528010913/http://www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Evolution_of_Technology/composites/Tech40.htm| archivedate =2010-05-28| deadurl =yes| df =}} Public domain content (see above reference)</ref>
Aluminium has a relatively high fracture toughness, allowing it to undergo large amounts of [[plastic deformation]] before failure. Composites, on the other hand, are less damage tolerant and undergo much less plastic deformation before failure. An airplane made entirely from aluminium can be repaired almost anywhere. This is not the case for composite materials, particularly as they use different and more exotic materials. Because of this, composites will probably always be used more in military aircraft, which are constantly being maintained, than in commercial aircraft, which have to require less maintenance.<ref name="CentComm"/> Aluminium still remains a remarkably useful material for aircraft structures and metallurgists have worked hard to develop better aluminium alloys, for example [[aluminium-lithium alloy]]s.

[http://article.pubs.nrc-cnrc.gc.ca/ppv/RPViewDoc?issn=1208-6029&volume=19&issue=2&startPage=363 Advanced composite materials with application to bridges]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} [[Image:Pu-phases.png|frame|A diagram of the [[Allotropy|allotropes]] of [[plutonium]] at ambient pressure. Atomic volumes in cubic [[angstrom]]s.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Phase !! Crystal Structure !! Density (g/cm3) |- ! alpha (α) | simple monoclinic || 19.86 |- ! beta (β) | body-centered monoclinic | 17.70 |- ! gamma (γ) | face-centered orthorhombic | 17.14 |- ! delta (δ) | face-centered cubic | 15.92 |- ! delta 
prime (δ′) | body-centered tetragonal | 16.00 |- ! epsilon (ε) | body-centered cubic | 16.51 |} {{cite journal | url = http://library.lanl.gov/cgi-bin/getfile?07-16.pdf | title = Plutonium: A Wartime Nightmare but a Metallurgist's Dream | last = Baker | first = Richard D. |author2= Hecker, Siegfried S.|author3= Harbur, Delbert R. | journal = [[Los Alamos Science]] | date = Winter–Spring 1983 | publisher = Los Alamos National Laboratory | pages = 148, 150–151 }}]] [[Plutonium]] occurs in a variety of [[Allotropy|allotropes]], even at ambient pressure. These allotropes differ widely in crystal structure and density; the α and δ allotropes differ in density by more than 25% at constant pressure. ==Overview== Plutonium normally has six allotropes and forms a seventh (zeta, ζ) under high temperature and a limited pressure range. These allotropes have very similar [[internal energy|energy level]]s but significantly varying [[density|densities]] and [[crystal structure]]s. This makes plutonium very sensitive to changes in temperature, pressure, or chemistry, and allows for dramatic volume changes following [[phase transition]]s. {{cite journal | first = Siegfried S. | last = Hecker | title = Plutonium and its alloys: from atoms to microstructure | journal = Los Alamos Science | volume = 26 | year = 2000 | pages = 290–335 | url = https://fas.org/sgp/othergov/doe/lanl/pubs/00818035.pdf | format = PDF }} Unlike most materials, plutonium ''increases'' in density when it melts, by 2.5%, but the liquid metal exhibits a linear decrease in density with temperature.{{cite book |title = The Encyclopedia of the Chemical Elements |publisher = Reinhold Book Corporation |location = New York |year = 1968 |editor = Clifford A. Hampel |last = Miner |first = William N. |author2=Schonfeld, Fred W. |chapter = Plutonium |page = 544 }} Densities of the different allotropes vary from 16.00 g/cm3 to 19.86 g/cm3. ==Machining plutonium== The presence of these many allotropes makes machining plutonium very difficult, as it changes state very readily. For example, the α phase exists at room temperature in unalloyed plutonium. It has machining characteristics similar to [[cast iron]] but changes to the β phase (''beta phase'') at slightly higher temperatures. The reasons for the complicated phase diagram are not entirely understood; recent research has focused on constructing accurate computer models of the phase transitions. The α phase has a low-symmetry [[monoclinic crystal system|monoclinic]] structure, hence its poor conductivity, brittleness, strength and compressibility. ==Stabilization== Plutonium in the δ phase (''delta phase'') normally exists in the 310 °C to 452 °C range but is stable at room temperature when [[alloy]]ed with a small percentage of [[gallium]], [[aluminium]], or [[cerium]], enhancing workability and allowing it to be [[welding|welded]] in weapons applications. The delta phase has more typical metallic character, and is roughly as strong and malleable as aluminium. In fission weapons, the explosive [[shock wave]]s used to compress a [[plutonium core]] will also cause a transition from the usual delta phase plutonium to the denser alpha phase, significantly helping to achieve [[supercriticality]].[http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/intro/pu-phase.htm Plutonium Crystal Phase Transitions]. Globalsecurity.org (2005-04-27). Retrieved on 2010-02-08. The [[plutonium-gallium alloy]] is the most common δ-stabilized alloy. [[Gallium]], [[aluminium]], [[americium]], [[scandium]] and [[cerium]] can stabilize the δ phase of plutonium for room temperature. [[Silicon]], [[indium]], [[zinc]] and [[zirconium]] allow formation of metastable δ state when rapidly cooled. High amount of [[hafnium]], [[holmium]] and [[thallium]] also allows retaining some of the δ phase at room temperature. [[Neptunium]] is the only element that can stabilize the α phase at higher temperatures. [[Titanium]], [[hafnium]] and [[zirconium]] stabilize the β phase at room temperature when rapidly cooled. [[File:Phase diagram of plutonium (1975) 150 kbar region.png|thumb|Phase diagram of plutonium (1975 data){{cite web|url=http://www.osti.gov/bridge/servlets/purl/4010212-0BbwUC/4010212.pdf|title=Phase Diagrams of the Elements|author=David A. Young|date=11 September 1975|publisher=Lawrence Livermore Laboratory}}]] [[File:Phase diagram of plutonium (1975).png|thumb|Phase diagram detail for lower pressures]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Allotropes Of Plutonium}} [[Category:Allotropy]] [[Category:Plutonium]]

[[File:SoSL Fabric 1927.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Aluminized skin fabric from the ''[[Spirit of St. Louis]]''.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/21/science/man-and-craft-were-one-as-a-new-age-began.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |title=Man and Craft Were One, As a New Age Began |author=John Noble Wilford |date=May 21, 2002 |journal=New York Times}}</ref>]] '''Aluminized cloth''' is a material designed to reflect thermal radiation. Applications include [[fire proximity suit]]s,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wren | first1 = J. E. | last2 = Scott | first2 = W. D. | last3 = Bates | first3 = C. E. | doi = 10.1080/00028897708984404 | title = Thermal and mechanical properties of aluminized fabrics for use in ferrous metal handling operations | journal = American Industrial Hygiene Association Journal | volume = 38 | issue = 11 | pages = 603–612 | year = 1977 | pmid = 930809| pmc = }}</ref> emergency [[space blanket]]s,<ref>{{cite book |title=Ladies' Home Journal Family Medical Guide |authorlink=Alan Edward Nourse |last=Nourse |first=Alan Edward |page=138 |year=1973 |publisher=[[Harper & Row]] |isbn=9780060132231 }}</ref> protection in molten metal handling,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wren|first1=James E.|last2=Scott |first2=William D. |last3=Bates |first3=Charles E. |title=Thermal and mechanical properties of aluminized fabrics for use in ferrous metal handling operations|journal=American Industrial Hygiene Association Journal|year=1977|volume=38|issue=11|pages=603–612|doi=10.1080/00028897708984404|pmid=930809}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Barker|first=Roger L.|author2=Muzaffer Yener|title=Evaluating the Resistance of Some Protective Fabrics to Molten Iron|journal=Textile Research journal |year=1981 |volume=51 |issue=8 |pages=533–541 |doi=10.1177/004051758105100807}}</ref> and insulation for building and containers.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Stogryn | first1 = A. | last2 = Desargant | first2 = G. | doi = 10.1109/TAP.1985.1143610 | title = The dielectric properties of brine in sea ice at microwave frequencies | journal = IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation | volume = 33 | issue = 5 | pages = 523 | year = 1985 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
[[Aluminium powder]] was added to [[aircraft dope]] which was then used to give a shiny finish to [[aircraft fabric covering|fabric-covered aircraft]], so protecting them from sunlight. The [[LZ 129 Hindenburg|Hindenburg airship]] was treated in this way and it has been suggested that the aluminium powder made the skin more combustible and so caused or contributed to the [[Hindenburg disaster]]. This theory is controversial and experiments have been conducted to test the hypothesis.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.airships.net/hindenburg/disaster/myths |title=Myths about the Hindenburg Crash}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Fire proximity suit]] * [[Reflectivity]] * [[Space blanket]] * [[Thermal insulation]] * [[MythBusters (2007 season)#Hindenburg Mystery]]

{| class="infobox" style="width: 300px;" |- | style="white-space:nowrap;" | {| cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style="background-color: white;" |- |[[File:Lakota MS PV array 2.jpg|x133px]] [[File:Thin Film Flexible Solar PV Ken Fields 1.JPG|x133px]] |- | style="padding: 10px 0;" | [[File:A-Si structure.jpg|300px]] |- | [[File:Solar calculator casio fx115ES crop.jpg|300px]] |} |- |Amorphous silicon: *Thin-film silicon solar panels on rooftop *Schematic structures of [[crystalline silicon]], amorphous silicon, and amorphous [[hydrogenated]] silicon *[[Solar-powered calculator|Solar calculator]] with amorphous [[solar cell]] (upper right corner) and [[liquid-crystal display|LCDs.]] |}
'''Amorphous silicon''' ('''a-Si''') is the non-[[crystalline]] form of [[silicon]] used for solar cells and [[thin-film transistor]]s in [[liquid-crystal display|LCDs]].
Used as [[semiconductor material]] for '''a-Si solar cells''', or '''thin-film silicon solar cells''', it is deposited in [[thin film]]s<!--at low temperatures--> onto a variety of flexible substrates, such as glass, metal and plastic. Amorphous silicon cells generally feature low efficiency, but are one of the most environmentally friendly [[photovoltaic]] technologies, since they do not use any [[toxic heavy metal]]s such as cadmium or lead.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
As a second-generation [[thin-film solar cell]] technology, amorphous silicon was once expected to become a major contributor in the [[Growth of photovoltaics|fast-growing]] worldwide photovoltaic market, but has since lost its significance due to strong competition from conventional [[crystalline silicon]] cells and other thin-film technologies such as [[Cadmium telluride photovoltaics|CdTe]] and [[CIGS solar cell|CIGS]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Amorphous silicon differs from other [[allotropic]] variations, such as [[monocrystalline silicon]]—a single crystal, and [[polycrystalline silicon]], that consists of small grains, also known as [[crystallite]]s. <!-- - Redir: Hydrogenated amorphous silicon - In addition, amorphous silicon also offers some unique capabilities to a variety of other electronic applications. -->
==Description== Silicon is a fourfold coordinated atom that is normally [[tetrahedron|tetrahedrally]] bonded to four neighboring silicon atoms. In crystalline silicon (c-Si) this tetrahedral structure continues over a large range, thus forming a well-ordered crystal lattice.
In amorphous silicon this long range order is not present. Rather, the atoms form a continuous random network. Moreover, not all the atoms within amorphous silicon are fourfold coordinated. Due to the disordered nature of the material some atoms have a [[dangling bond]]. Physically, these dangling bonds represent defects in the continuous random network and may cause anomalous electrical behavior.
The material can be [[passivation (chemistry)|passivated]] by hydrogen, which bonds to the dangling bonds and can reduce the dangling bond density by several orders of magnitude. Hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) has a sufficiently low amount of defects to be used within devices such as solar [[photovoltaic]] cells, particularly in the [[protocrystalline]] growth regime.<ref>R.W. Collins, et al., "Evolution of microstructure and phase in amorphous, protocrystalline, and microcrystalline silicon studied by real time spectroscopic ellipsometry", ''Solar Energy Materials and Solar Cells'', 78(1-4), pp. 143-180, 2003.</ref> However, hydrogenation is associated with light-induced degradation of the material, termed the [[Staebler–Wronski effect]].<ref>C. R. Wronski, et al., "Intrinsic and Light Induced Gap States in a-Si:H Materials and Solar Cells - Effects of Microstructure", ''Thin Solid Films'', 451-452 pp. 470-475, 2004.</ref>
[[File:Schematic of allotropic forms of silcon horizontal plain.svg|thumb|center|550px|Schematic of allotropic forms of silicon: [[monocrystalline silicon|monocrystalline]], [[polycrystalline silicon|polycrystalline]], and amorphous silicon]]
==Amorphous silicon and carbon== Amorphous [[alloy]]s of silicon and carbon (amorphous silicon [[carbide]], also hydrogenated, a-Si<sub>1−x</sub>C<sub>x</sub>:H) are an interesting variant. Introduction of carbon atoms adds extra degrees of freedom for control of the properties of the material. The film could also be made [[transparency and translucency|transparent]] to visible light.
Increasing the concentration of carbon in the alloy widens the electronic gap between conduction and valence bands (also called "optical gap" and [[bandgap]]). This can potentially increase the light efficiency of solar cells made with amorphous silicon carbide layers. On the other hand, the electronic properties as a [[semiconductor]] (mainly [[electron mobility]]), are adversely affected by the increasing content of carbon in the alloy, due to the increased disorder in the atomic network.
Several studies are found in the scientific literature, mainly investigating the effects of deposition parameters on electronic quality, but practical applications of amorphous silicon carbide in commercial devices are still lacking.
==Properties== The density of amorphous Si has been calculated as 4.90×10<sup>22</sup> atom/cm<sup>3</sup> (2.285 g/cm<sup>3</sup>) at 300 K. This was done using thin (5 micron) strips of amorphous silicon. This density is 1.8±0.1% less dense than crystalline Si at 300 K.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Custer|first=J. S.|last2=Thompson|first2=Michael O.|last3=Jacobson|first3=D. C.|last4=Poate|first4=J. M.|last5=Roorda|first5=S.|last6=Sinke|first6=W. C.|last7=Spaepen|first7=F.|date=1994-01-24|title=Density of amorphous Si|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/apl/64/4/10.1063/1.111121|journal=Applied Physics Letters|volume=64|issue=4|pages=437–439|doi=10.1063/1.111121|issn=0003-6951}}</ref> Silicon is one of the few elements that expands upon cooling and has a lower density as a solid than as a liquid.
==Hydrogenated amorphous silicon== Unhydrogenated a-Si has a very high defect density which leads to undesirable semiconductor properties such as poor photoconductivity and prevents doping which is critical to engineering semiconductor properties. By introducing hydrogen during the fabrication of amorphous silicon, [[photoconductivity]] is significantly improved and doping is made possible. Hydrogenated amorphous silicon, a-Si:H, was first fabricated in 1969 by Chittick, Alexander and Sterling by deposition using a silane gas (SiH4) precursor. The resulting material showed a lower defect density and increased conductivity due to impurities. Interest in a-Si:H came when (in 1975), [[Peter LeComber|LeComber]] and [[Walter Eric Spear|Spear]] discovered the ability for substitutional doping of a-Si:H using phosphine (n-type) or diborane (p-type).<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zQMwsMt4VmoC|title=Hydrogenated Amorphous Silicon|last=Street|first=R. A.|date=2005-09-08|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521019347|language=en}}</ref> The role of hydrogen in reducing defects was verified by Paul's group at Harvard who found a hydrogen concentration of about 10 atomic % through IR vibration, which for Si-H bonds has a frequency of about 2000 cm<sup>−1</sup>.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Paul|first=William|last2=Anderson|first2=David A.|date=1981-09-01|title=Properties of amorphous hydrogenated silicon, with special emphasis on preparation by sputtering|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0165163381900010|journal=Solar Energy Materials|volume=5|issue=3|pages=229–316|doi=10.1016/0165-1633(81)90001-0}}</ref> Starting in the 1970s, a-Si:H was developed in solar cells by RCA by which steadily climbed in efficiency to about 13.6% in 2015.<ref>http://www.nrel.gov/pv/assets/images/efficiency_chart.jpg</ref>
==Deposition processes== {| class="wikitable" ! ![[Chemical vapor deposition|CVD]] ![[Plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition|PECVD]] !Catalytic CVD ![[Sputter deposition|Sputtering]] |- |Type of film |a-Si:H |a-Si:H |a-Si:H |a-Si |- |Unique application | |[[Large-area electronics]] | |Hydrogen-free deposition |- |Chamber temperature |600C |30–300C | |30–1000C |- |Active element temperature | | |2000C | |- |Chamber pressure |0.1–10 Torr |0.1–10 Torr | |0.001–0.1 Torr |- |Physical principle |[[Thermal decomposition|Thermolysis]] |Plasma-induced dissociation |Thermolysis |Ionization of Si source |- |Facilitators | | |[[Tungsten|W]]/[[Tantalum|Ta]] heated wires |[[Argon]] cations |- |Typical drive voltage | |RF 13.56 MHz; 0.01-1W/cm<sup>2</sup> | | |- |Si source |[[Silane|SiH<sub>4</sub>]] gas |SiH<sub>4</sub> gas |SiH<sub>4</sub> gas |Target |- |Substrate temperature |controllable |controllable |controllable |controllable |}
==Applications== While a-Si suffers from lower electronic performance compared to c-Si, it is much more flexible in its applications. For example, a-Si layers can be made thinner than c-Si, which may produce savings on silicon material cost.
One further advantage is that a-Si can be deposited at very low temperatures, e.g., as low as 75 degrees Celsius. This allows deposition on not only glass, but [[plastic electronics|plastic]] as well, making it a candidate for a [[roll-to-roll processing]] technique. Once deposited, a-Si can be [[doped]] in a fashion similar to c-Si, to form [[p-type semiconductor|p-type]] or [[n-type semiconductor|n-type]] layers and ultimately to form electronic devices.
Another advantage is that a-Si can be deposited over large areas by [[plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition|PECVD]]. The design of the PECVD system has great impact on the production cost of such panel, therefore most equipment suppliers put their focus on the design of PECVD for higher throughput, that leads to lower [[manufacturing cost]]<ref>{{cite journal |url= http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6TW0-4H16NVN-8&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_searchStrId=1005509540&_rerunOrigin=google&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=97a33054065ae2a5a59f8327ce400217 |title= Towards very low-cost mass production of thin-film silicon photovoltaic (PV) solar modules on glass |publisher= Elsevier B.V. |date=2005-09-02 |doi=10.1016/j.tsf.2005.07.299 |volume=502 |journal=Thin Solid Films |pages=292–299}}</ref> particularly when the [[silane]] is [[recycled]].<ref>M. A. Kreiger, et al., Life Cycle Analysis of Silane Recycling in Amorphous Silicon-Based Solar Photovoltaic Manufacturing, ''Resources, Conservation & Recycling'', 70, pp.44-49 (2013). https://www.academia.edu/2310926/Life_Cycle_Analysis_of_Silane_Recycling_in_Amorphous_Silicon-Based_Solar_Photovoltaic_Manufacturing</ref>
Arrays of small (under 1 mm by 1 mm) a-Si photodiodes on glass are used as visible-light [[image sensor]]s in some [[flat panel detector]]s for [[fluoroscopy]] and [[radiography]].
===Photovoltaics=== {{See also|Thin-film solar cell}} [[File:Vintage Teal Photon Solar Powered Electronic Pocket Calculator, LCD With Yellow Filter, One Of The First Solar Powered Calculators, Made In Japan, Circa 1978 (15083726059).jpg|thumb|The "Teal Photon" [[solar-powered calculator]] produced in the late 1970s]]
Amorphous silicon (a-Si) has been used as a [[photovoltaic]] [[solar cell]] material for devices which require very little power, such as pocket [[calculator]]s, because their lower performance compared to conventional [[crystalline silicon]] (c-Si) solar cells is more than offset by their simplified and lower cost of deposition onto a substrate. The first [[solar-powered calculator]]s were already available in the late 1970s, such as the Royal ''Solar 1'', Sharp ''EL-8026'', and Teal ''Photon''.
More recently, improvements in a-Si construction techniques have made them more attractive for large-area solar cell use as well. Here their lower inherent efficiency is made up, at least partially, by their thinness – higher efficiencies can be reached by stacking several thin-film cells on top of each other, each one tuned to work well at a specific frequency of light. This approach is not applicable to c-Si cells, which are thick as a result of its [[Direct and indirect band gaps|indirect band-gap]] and are therefore largely opaque, blocking light from reaching other layers in a stack.
The source of the low efficiency of amorphous silicon photovoltaics is due largely to the low [[hole mobility]] of the material.<ref name="LiangSchiff2006">{{cite journal|last1=Liang|first1=Jianjun|last2=Schiff|first2=E. A.|last3=Guha|first3=S.|last4=Yan|first4=Baojie|last5=Yang|first5=J.|title=Hole-mobility limit of amorphous silicon solar cells|journal=Applied Physics Letters|volume=88|issue=6|year=2006|pages=063512|issn=0003-6951|doi=10.1063/1.2170405|url=http://surface.syr.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1036&context=phy}}</ref> This low hole mobility has been attributed to many physical aspects of the material, including the presence of [[dangling bonds]] (silicon with 3 bonds),<ref name="SmithWagner1987">{{cite journal|last1=Smith|first1=Z E.|last2=Wagner|first2=S.|title=Band tails, entropy, and equilibrium defects in hydrogenated amorphous silicon|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=59|issue=6|year=1987|pages=688–691|issn=0031-9007|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.59.688|bibcode=1987PhRvL..59..688S|pmid=10035845}}</ref> floating bonds (silicon with 5 bonds),<ref name="Stathis1989">{{cite journal|last1=Stathis|first1=J. H.|title=Analysis of the superhyperfine structure and the g-tensor of defects in amorphous silicon|journal=Physical Review B|volume=40|issue=2|year=1989|pages=1232–1237|issn=0163-1829|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.40.1232}}</ref> as well as bond reconfigurations.<ref name="JohlinWagner2013">{{cite journal|last1=Johlin|first1=Eric|last2=Wagner|first2=Lucas K.|last3=Buonassisi|first3=Tonio|last4=Grossman|first4=Jeffrey C.|title=Origins of Structural Hole Traps in Hydrogenated Amorphous Silicon|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=110|issue=14|year=2013|issn=0031-9007|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.110.146805|bibcode=2013PhRvL.110n6805J|pmid=25167024|pages=146805}}</ref> While much work has been done to control these sources of low mobility, evidence suggests that the multitude of interacting defects may lead to the mobility being inherently limited, as reducing one type of defect leads to formation others.<ref name="JohlinSimmons2014">{{cite journal|last1=Johlin|first1=Eric|last2=Simmons|first2=C. B.|last3=Buonassisi|first3=Tonio|last4=Grossman|first4=Jeffrey C.|title=Hole-mobility-limiting atomic structures in hydrogenated amorphous silicon|journal=Physical Review B|volume=90|issue=10|year=2014|issn=1098-0121|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.90.104103}}</ref>
The main advantage of a-Si in large scale production is not efficiency, but cost. a-Si cells use only a fraction of the silicon needed for typical c-Si cells, and the cost of the silicon has historically been a significant contributor to cell cost. However, the higher costs of manufacture due to the multi-layer construction have, to date, made a-Si unattractive except in roles where their thinness or flexibility are an advantage.<ref>By Eric Wesoff, Greentech Media. "[http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/The-End-of-Oerlikons-Amorphous-Silicon-Solar-Saga The End of Oerlikon’s Amorphous Silicon Solar Saga]." January 31, 2014. February 19, 2016.</ref>
Typically, amorphous silicon thin-film cells use a [[p-i-n]] structure. The placement of the p-type layer on top is also due to the lower hole mobility, allowing the holes to traverse a shorter average distance for collection to the top contact. Typical panel structure includes front side glass, [[Transparent conducting oxide|TCO]], thin-film silicon, back contact, [[polyvinyl butyral]] (PVB) and back side glass. Uni-Solar, a division of [[Energy Conversion Devices]] produced a version of flexible backings, used in roll-on roofing products. However, the world's largest manufacturer of amorphous silicon photovoltaics had to file for bankruptcy in 2012, as it could not compete with the rapidly declining prices of conventional [[solar panel]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/The-End-Arrives-For-ECD-Solar- |title=The End Arrives for ECD Solar |work=GreentechMedia |date=14 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/Oerlikon-Divests-its-Solar-Business-and-the-Fate-of-Amorphous-Silicon-Solar |title=Oerlikon Divests Its Solar Business and the Fate of Amorphous Silicon PV |work=GrrentechMedia |date=March 2, 2012}}</ref>
====Microcrystalline and micromorphous silicon==== {{Main|Nanocrystalline silicon|Micromorph}} Microcrystalline silicon (also called nanocrystalline silicon) is amorphous silicon, but also contains small crystals. It absorbs a broader spectrum of light and is [[flexible electronics|flexible]]. [[Micromorph]]ous silicon [[photovoltaic module|module]] technology combines two different types of silicon, amorphous and microcrystalline silicon, in a top and a bottom [[photovoltaic cell]]. Sharp produces cells using this system in order to more efficiently capture blue light, increasing the efficiency of the cells during the time where there is no direct sunlight falling on them. [[Protocrystalline]] silicon is often used to optimize the open circuit voltage of a-Si photovoltaics.
====Large-scale production==== [[Xunlight Corporation]], which has received over $40 million of institutional investments,{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} has completed the installation of its first 25 MW wide-web, [[roll-to-roll]] photovoltaic manufacturing equipment for the production of thin-film silicon PV modules.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.xunlight.com/2009/10/june-22-2009-xunlight-completes-installation-of-its-first-25-megawatt/ |title=Xunlight Completes Installation of its First 25 Megawatt Wide-Web Roll-to-Roll Photovoltaic Manufacturing Equipment |date=June 22, 2009 |publisher=Xunlight}}</ref> [[Anwell Technologies]] has also completed the installation of its first 40 MW a-Si thin film solar panel manufacturing facility in Henan with its in-house designed multi-substrate-multi-chamber PECVD equipment.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.solarbuzz.com/news/NewsASMA255.htm |title= Anwell Produces its First Thin Film Solar Panel | publisher= Solarbuzz |date= September 7, 2009}}</ref>
====Photovoltaic thermal hybrid solar collectors==== [[Photovoltaic thermal hybrid solar collector]]s (PVT), are systems that convert [[solar radiation]] into [[electrical energy]] and [[thermal energy]]. These systems combine a solar cell, which converts [[electromagnetic radiation]] ([[photon]]s) into electricity, with a [[solar thermal collector]], which captures the remaining energy and removes waste heat from the solar PV module. Solar cells suffer from a drop in efficiency with the rise in temperature due to increased [[solar cell#Cell temperature|resistance]]. Most such systems can be engineered to carry heat away from the solar cells thereby cooling the cells and thus improving their efficiency by lowering resistance.<ref>S.A. Kalogirou, Y. Tripanagnostopoulos (30 January 2006). These systems are most often used for domestic hot water (DHW) and electricity production</ref> Although this is an effective method, it causes the thermal component to under-perform compared to a [[solar thermal]] collector. Recent research showed that a-Si:H PV with low temperature coefficients allow the PVT to be operated at high temperatures, creating a more symbiotic PVT system and improving performance of the a-Si:H PV by about 10%.
===Thin-film-transistor liquid-crystal display=== {{Main|Thin-film-transistor liquid-crystal display}}
Amorphous silicon has become the material of choice for the active layer in [[thin-film transistor]]s (TFTs), which are most widely used in [[large-area electronics]] applications, mainly for [[liquid-crystal display]]s (LCDs).
[[Thin-film-transistor liquid-crystal display]] (TFT-LCD) show a similar circuit layout process to that of semiconductor products. However, rather than fabricating the transistors from silicon, that is formed into a crystalline silicon [[wafer]], they are made from a thin film of amorphous silicon that is deposited on a [[glass]] panel. The silicon layer for TFT-LCDs is typically deposited using the [[Plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition|PECVD]] process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plasma.com/classroom/fabricating_tft_lcd.htm |title=TFT LCD - Fabricating TFT LCD |publisher=Plasma.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502060952/http://www.plasma.com/classroom/fabricating_tft_lcd.htm |archivedate=2013-05-02 |df= }}</ref> Transistors take up only a small fraction of the area of each pixel and the rest of the silicon film is etched away to allow light to easily pass through it.
[[Polycrystalline silicon]] is sometimes used in displays requiring higher TFT performance. Examples include small high-resolution displays such as those found in projectors or viewfinders. Amorphous silicon-based TFTs are by far the most common, due to their lower production cost, whereas polycrystalline silicon TFTs are more costly and much more difficult to produce.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plasma.com/classroom/what_is_tft_lcd.htm |title=TFT LCD - Electronic Aspects of LCD TVs and LCD Monitors |publisher=Plasma.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130823203913/http://www.plasma.com/classroom/what_is_tft_lcd.htm |archivedate=2013-08-23 }}</ref>
==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Atomic layer deposition]] (ALD) *[[Chemical-mechanical planarization]] (CMP) *[[Chemical vapor deposition]] (CVD) *[[Crystalline silicon]] *[[Ion implantation]] *[[Nanoparticle]] *[[Physical vapor deposition]] (PVD) *[[Protocrystalline]] *[[Rapid thermal processing]] (RTP) {{Div col end}}

The '''anaerobic clarigester''' is a form of [[anaerobic digester]]. It is regarded as being the ancestor of the [[upflow anaerobic sludge blanket digestion]] (UASB) anaerobic digester.<ref>[http://www.uasb.org/discover/agsb.htm UASB Homepage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060706215607/http://www.uasb.org/discover/agsb.htm |date=July 6, 2006 }}</ref> A clarigester treats dilute biodegradable feedstocks and separates out solid and hydraulic (liquid) retention times. A diagram comparing the UASB, anaerobic clarigester and [[anaerobic contact process]]es can be found [http://www.fao.org/docrep/t0541e/T0541E02.GIF here].

{{Infobox film | name = Borealis | image = Borealis poster.jpg | alt = | caption = | director = [[Frank Wolf (filmmaker)|Frank Wolf]] | producer = <!-- or: |producers = --> | writer = <!-- or: |writers = --> | starring = Taku Hokoyama, Frank Wolf | music = Grant Baldwin | cinematography = | editing = | studio = <!-- or: |production companies = --> | distributor = <!-- or: |distributors = --> | released = {{film date|2008}} | runtime = 63 minutes | country = Canada | language = English | budget = | gross = <!--(please use condensed and rounded values, e.g. "£11.6 million" not "£11,586,221")--> }} '''''Borealis''''' is a 2008 documentary film by [[Frank Wolf (filmmaker)|Frank Wolf]] that follows two friends on a 3,100 km canoe adventure through the northern [[Boreal forest of Canada|Boreal forest]] of Manitoba and Ontario. The film looks at the industrial threats to the pristine, vast wilderness north of the 51st parallel from the perspective of those who live in the region. The film is notable for its quirky and humorous tone in spite of the subject matter. It won the Grand Prize as well as Prize for Best Canadian Film at the 2009 Vancouver International Mountain Film Festival<ref>{{cite web|title=Borealis the Grand Prize Winner at 2009 VIMFF |url=http://www.vimff.org/archive/www.vimff.org/pages29ded.html?portalid=2&pageid=22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726002706/http://www.vimff.org/archive/www.vimff.org/pages29ded.html?portalid=2&pageid=22 |archivedate=2014-07-26 |df= }}</ref> and was one of the Top Ten Most Popular Canadian Films at the 2008 [[Vancouver International Film Festival]]. It aired multiple times on CBC's [[documentary (TV channel)|documentary]] in Canada in 2009-10.
==About the Filmmaker== Frank Wolf (born in 1970) is an award-winning, Canadian filmmaker, adventurer, writer and environmentalist. Wolf's creative works specialize in adventure and environmental documentary film. His handful of films include Wild Ones, [[The Hand of Franklin]], [[Kitturiaq]], On the Line, [[Mammalian]], and Borealis, all of which broadcast on CBC's documentary channel in Canada. Wolf, acts as starring role and director in his films, using a humorous approach in order to make the environmentalist and adventurer documentaries appealing to a broader audience.
==Awards== •2008 Vancouver International Film Festival Official Selection: runner-up for NFB audience award, best documentary
•2009 Vancouver International Mountain Film Festival Official Selection: winner of Grand Prize for best overall film, winner of prize for best Canadian film
•2009 Beloit International Film Festival Official Selection
•2009 Powell River Film Festival Official Selection
•2009 Reel Paddling Film Festival Official Selection
•2009 New Zealand Mountain Film Festival Official Selection
==Reviews== "The challenge of making this film was almost as severe as the challenge of the journey it depicts. The makers showed great imagination to get around the limitations of a zero budget, livening up the narrative with interviews, jokes, sight gags, even dance! It gently raised important issues along the way, allowing these issues to arise quite naturally out of the journey itself." -VIMFF Jury Statement for Grand Prize winner 'Borealis'
"An appealing ground-level spin on environmental issues" - The Vancouver Province

{{globalize|date=July 2011}} [[File:Stained wooden clapboard siding.jpg|thumb|Clapboard siding [[wood stain|stained]] dark brown]] [[File:Saltbox Concord 2 cropped.jpg|thumb|Captain William Smith House at [[Minute Man National Historical Park]], a restored [[saltbox]] style house with unpainted clapboard siding]] [[File:Quaker Hill Historic District - 149 Old Norwich Rd, New London County CT.jpg|thumb|[[Dutch Colonial Revival architecture|Dutch Colonial Revival]] house built in weatherboard in [[New London, Connecticut]]]] [[File:Period weatherboard, Dunedin, NZ.jpg|thumb|Period weatherboard house in [[Dunedin]], New Zealand]] [[File:Weatherboarded Cottage, Petteridge. - geograph.org.uk - 191922.jpg|thumb|Weatherboarded Cottage, Petteridge. This style of building is very common in rural west Kent, England]] [[File:Ephraim Hawley House close up beaded oak clapboards.JPG|thumb|Very old, beaded oak clapboards on the right, modern clapboard siding on the left.]] [[File:George W Young House cabin Northeast elevation.jpg|thumb|right|Clapboard siding also known weatherboard used to cover over flat, squared logs in [[log house|log house construction]]]]
'''Clapboard''' or '''clabbard''', also called '''bevel siding''', '''lap siding''', and '''weatherboard''', with regional variation in the definition of these terms, is wooden [[siding]] of a building in the form of horizontal boards, often overlapping.
==Definition== ''Clapboard'' in modern (American English) usage is a word for long, thin boards used to cover walls and (formerly) roofs of buildings.<ref name="etymonline.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?allowed_in_frame=0&search=clapboard&searchmode=none|title=Online Etymology Dictionary|publisher=|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref> Also historically called ''clawboards'' and ''cloboards''.<ref>Whitney, William Dwight. "Clapboard" def. 1. ''The Century dictionary; an encyclopedic lexicon of the English language'',. New York: The Century Co., 188991. Print.</ref>
An older meaning of clapboard is small, split pieces of oak imported from Germany for use as [[barrel]] staves, and the name is a partial translation of Middle Dutch ''klapholt'' and related to German ''Klappholz''.<ref name="etymonline.com"/>
==Types== ===Riven=== Clapboards were originally [[Wood splitting|riven]] radially producing [[triangle|triangular]] or "feather-edged" sections, attached thin side up and overlapped thick over thin to shed water.<ref>[http://www.popularwoodworking.com/article/Finish_Both_Sides_Not_Necessary/ Heart side of boards]. ''PopularWoodworking.com''.</ref>
===Radially sawn=== Later, the boards were [[Rift sawing|radially sawn]] in a type of [[sawmill]] called a ''clapboard mill'', producing ''vertical-grain'' clapboards. The more commonly used boards in [[New England]] are vertical-grain boards. Depending on the diameter of the log, cuts are made from 4½" to 6½" deep along the full length of the log. Each time the log turns for the next cut, it is rotated ⅝" until it has turned 360°. This gives the radially sawn clapboard its taper and true vertical grain.
===Flat-sawn=== ''Flat-grain'' clapboards are cut tangent to the annual growth rings of the tree. As this technique was common in most parts of the [[British Isles]], it was carried by immigrants to their colonies in the [[Americas]] and in [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. Flat-sawn wood [[Wood warping|cups]] more and does not hold paint as well as radially sawn wood.
===Chamferboard=== [[File:Chamferboard house exterior (closeup), Brisbane, 2015.JPG|thumb|Chamferboard house exterior (closeup), Brisbane, 2015]] ''Chamferboards'' are an Australian form of weatherboarding using tongue-and-groove joints to link the boards together to give a flatter external appearance than regular angled weatherboards.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chamferboard|url=http://www.abis.com.au/chamferboard|publisher=Australian Building Inspection Services|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref>
===Finger jointed=== Some modern clapboards are made up of shorter pieces of wood ''finger jointed'' together with an adhesive.
==Wood species== In North America clapboards were historically made of split oak, pine and spruce. Modern clapboards are available in red cedar and pine.
In some areas, clapboards were traditionally left as raw wood, relying upon good air circulation and the use of 'semi-hardwoods' to keep the boards from rotting. These boards eventually go grey as the tannins are washed out from the wood. More recently clapboard has been tarred or painted—traditionally black or white due to locally occurring minerals or pigments. In modern clapboard these colors remain popular, but with a hugely wider variety due to chemical pigments and stains.
Clapboard houses may be found in most parts of the British Isles, and the style may be part of all types of traditional building, from cottages to windmills, shops to workshops, as well as many others.
In [[New Zealand]], clapboard housing dominates buildings before 1960. Clapboard, with a corrugated iron roof, was found to be a cost-effective building style. After the big [[earthquakes]] of 1855 and 1931, wooden buildings were perceived as being less vulnerable to damage. Clapboard is always referred to as 'weatherboard' in New Zealand.
Newer, cheaper designs often imitate the form of clapboard construction as "[[siding]]" made of [[vinyl siding|vinyl]] ([[Polyvinyl chloride#Unplasticized polyvinyl chloride (uPVC)|uPVC]]), [[aluminum]], [[fiber cement siding|fiber cement]], or other man-made materials.
