[[Image:PlanePair2.jpg|right|thumb|Modern 3D Lichtenberg figures or "[[electrical treeing]]" in a block of clear acrylic, created by irradiating the block with an [[electron beam]]. Actual size: {{cvt|3|×|3|×|2|in|mm}}]] [[Image:Lightning injury.jpg|thumb|Slight branching redness traveling up the leg of a person created by current from a nearby lightning strike]]
'''Lichtenberg figures''' (German ''Lichtenberg-Figuren''), or "Lichtenberg dust figures", are branching [[electric discharge]]s that sometimes appear on the surface or in the interior of [[Electrical insulation|insulating materials]]. Lichtenberg figures are often associated with the progressive deterioration of high voltage components and equipment. The study of planar Lichtenberg figures along insulating surfaces and 3D [[Electrical treeing|electrical trees]] within insulating materials often provides engineers with valuable insights for improving the long-term reliability of high voltage equipment. Lichtenberg figures are now known to occur on or within solids, liquids, and gases during [[electrical breakdown]].
==History== Lichtenberg figures are named after the German physicist [[Georg Christoph Lichtenberg]], who originally discovered and studied them. When they were first discovered, it was thought that their characteristic shapes might help to reveal the nature of positive and negative electric "fluids". In 1777, Lichtenberg built a large [[electrophorus]] to generate high [[voltage]] [[static electricity]] through [[Electrostatic induction|induction]]. After discharging a high voltage point to the surface of an insulator, he recorded the resulting radial patterns by sprinkling various powdered materials onto the surface. By then pressing blank sheets of paper onto these patterns, Lichtenberg was able to transfer and record these images, thereby discovering the basic principle of modern [[xerography]].<ref>De Nova Methodo Naturam Ac Motum Fluidi Electrici Investigandi (Göttinger Novi Commentarii, Göttingen, 1777). The English translation from the Latin title is, "Concerning the New Method Of Investigating the Nature and Movement of Electric Fluid"</ref>
This discovery was also the forerunner of the modern day science of [[plasma (physics)|plasma physics]]. Although Lichtenberg only studied two-dimensional (2D) figures, modern high voltage researchers study 2D and 3D figures ([[electrical tree]]s) on, and within, insulating materials. Lichtenberg figures are now known to be examples of [[fractals]].
== Formation == Two-dimensional (2D) Lichtenberg figures can be produced by placing a sharp-pointed needle perpendicular to the surface of a non-conducting plate, such as of [[resin]], [[ebonite]], or [[glass]]. The point is positioned very near or contacting the plate. A source of high voltage, such as a [[Leyden jar]] (a type of [[capacitor]]) or a [[static electricity]] generator, is applied to the needle, typically through a [[spark gap]]. This creates a sudden, small [[Electrostatic discharge|electrical discharge]] along the surface of the plate. This deposits stranded areas of charge onto the surface of the plate. These electrified areas are then tested by sprinkling a mixture of powdered flowers of [[sulfur]] and red lead (Pb<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> or [[lead tetroxide]]) onto the plate.<ref>"Two Hundred Years of Lichtenberg Figures" by Yuzo Takahashi, Journal of Electrostatics, Volume 6, Issue 1, February 1979, Pages 1-13.</ref>
During handling, powdered sulfur tends to acquire a slight negative charge, while red lead tends to acquire a slight positive charge. The negatively electrified sulfur is attracted to the positively electrified areas of the plate, while the positively electrified red lead is attracted to the negatively electrified areas. In addition to the distribution of colors thereby produced, there is also a marked difference in the form of the figure, according to the polarity of the electrical charge that was applied to the plate. If the charge areas were positive, a widely extending patch is seen on the plate, consisting of a dense nucleus, from which branches radiate in all directions. Negatively charged areas are considerably smaller and have a sharp circular or fan-like boundary entirely devoid of branches. [[Heinrich Rudolf Hertz]] employed Lichtenberg dust figures in his seminal work proving [[James Clerk Maxwell|Maxwell's]] electromagnetic wave theories.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hertz|first=Heinrich Rudolf|title=Electric waves: being researches on the propagation of electric action with finite velocity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jyRWAAAAMAAJ&dq=Heinrich%20Rudolf%20Hertz%20Electric%20waves%3A%20being%20researches%20on%20the%20propagation%20of%20electric%20action%20with%20finite%20velocity&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
[[File:Tracking1.jpg|thumb|Carbonized high-voltage discharge tracks cross the surface of a [[polycarbonate]] sheet]] If the plate receives a mixture of positive and negative charges as, for example, from an [[induction coil]], a mixed figure results, consisting of a large red central nucleus, corresponding to the negative charge, surrounded by yellow rays, corresponding to the positive charge. The difference between positive and negative figures seems to depend on the presence of [[air]]; for the difference tends to disappear when the experiment is conducted in [[vacuum]]. [[Peter Theophil Riess|Peter T. Riess]] (a 19th-century researcher) theorized that the negative electrification of the plate was caused by the friction of the water vapour, etc., driven along the surface by the [[explosion]] which accompanies the [[disruptive discharge]] at the point. This electrification would favor the spread of a positive, but hinder that of a negative discharge.<ref>"Ueber elektrische Figuren und Bilde" by Riess, Peter Theophil, Annalen der Physik und Chemie, ISSN 0003-3804, 1846, Volume 145, Issue 9, pages 1-44</ref>
It is now known that electrical charges are transferred to the insulator's surface through small spark discharges that occur along the boundary between the gas and insulator surface.<ref>"The Atomphysical Interpretation of Lichtenberg Figures and Their Application to the Study of Gas Discharge Phenomena" by F. H. Merrill and A. Von Hippel, Journal of Applied Physics, December 1939, Volume 10, Issue 12, pp. 873-887</ref> Once transferred to the insulator, these excess charges become temporarily stranded. The shapes of the resulting charge distributions reflect the shape of the spark discharges which, in turn, depend on the high voltage polarity and pressure of the gas. Using a higher applied voltage will generate larger diameter and more branched figures. It is now known that positive Lichtenberg figures have longer, branching structures because long sparks within air can more easily form and propagate from positively charged high voltage terminals. This property has been used to measure the transient voltage polarity and magnitude of lightning surges on electrical power lines.<ref>"The Klydonograph and Its Application to Surge Investigation" by J. H. Cox and J. W. Legg, Transactions of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, January, 1925.</ref>
Another type of 2D Lichtenberg figure can be created when an insulating surface becomes contaminated with semiconducting material. When a high voltage is applied across the surface, leakage currents may cause localized heating and progressive degradation and charring of the underlying material. Over time, branching, tree-like carbonized patterns are formed upon the surface of the insulator called [[electrical tree]]s. This degradation process is called ''tracking''. If the conductive paths ultimately bridge the insulating space, the result is catastrophic failure of the insulating material. Some artists purposely apply salt water to the surface of wood or cardboard and then apply a high voltage across the surface to generate complex carbonized 2D Lichtenberg figures on the surface.<ref>http://www.turningart.com/artists/artist-cory-hunter</ref>
=== Fractal similarities === The branching, [[self-similar]] patterns observed in Lichtenberg figures exhibit [[fractal]] properties. Lichtenberg figures often develop during the [[dielectric breakdown]] of solids, liquids, and even gases. Their appearance and growth appear to be related to a process called [[diffusion-limited aggregation]] (DLA). A useful macroscopic model that combines an electric field with DLA was developed by Niemeyer, Pietronero, and Weismann in 1984, and is known as the [[dielectric breakdown model]] (DBM).<ref>"Fractal Dimension of Dielectric Breakdown" by L. Niemeyer, L. Pietronero*, and H. J. Wiesmann, Phys. Rev. Lett. 52, 1033–1036 (1984)</ref>
Although the electrical breakdown mechanisms of air and PMMA plastic are considerably different, the branching discharges turn out to be related. So, it should not be surprising that the branching forms taken by natural lightning also have fractal characteristics.<ref>"The Fractal Nature of Lightning: An Investigation of the Fractal Relationship of the Structure of Lightning to Terrain" by Brian Clay Graham-Jones, a thesis submitted to the Department of Mathematics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science, Florida State University, College of Arts and Sciences, 2006</ref>
== Natural occurrences == [[Image:Lightning in Arlington.jpg|right|thumb|[[Lightning]] is a naturally occurring 3-dimensional Lichtenberg figure]] Lichtenberg figures may also appear on the skin of [[lightning]] strike victims. These are reddish, fernlike patterns that may persist for hours or days. They are also a useful indicator for medical examiners when determining the cause of death. Lichtenberg figures appearing on people are sometimes called '''lightning flowers''', and they are thought to be caused by the rupture of [[capillaries]] under the skin due to the passage of the lightning current or the [[shock wave]] from the lightning discharge as it flashes over the skin.<ref>"Lichtenberg Figures Due to a Lightning Strike" by Yves Domart, M.D., Emmanuel Garet, M.D., New England Journal of Medicine, Volume 343:1536, November 23, 2000, Number 21, Images in Clinical Medicine</ref>
A lightning strike can also create a large Lichtenberg figure in grass surrounding the point struck. These are sometimes found on [[golf course]]s or in grassy meadows.<ref>"Lightning and Lichtenberg Figures" by Michael Cherington, Sheryl Olson and Philip R. Yarnell, Injury: International Journal of the Care of the Injured, Volume 34, Issue 5, May 2003, Pages 367-371</ref> Branching root-shaped "[[fulgurite]]" mineral deposits may also be created as [[sand]] and [[soil]] is fused into glassy tubes by the intense heat of the current.
[[Electrical treeing]] often occurs in high-voltage equipment prior to causing complete breakdown. Following these Lichtenberg figures within the insulation during post-accident investigation of an insulation failure can be useful in finding the cause of breakdown. An experienced high-voltage engineer can see from the direction and the shape of trees and their branches where the primary cause of the breakdown was situated and possibly find the initial cause. Broken-down transformers, high-voltage cables, bushings and other equipment can usefully be investigated in this manner. The insulation is unrolled (in the case of paper insulation) or sliced in thin slices (in the case of solid insulating materials). The results are then sketched or photographed to create a record of the breakdown process.
== In insulating materials == Modern Lichtenberg figures can also be created within solid insulating materials, such as acrylic (polymethyl methacrylate or [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|PMMA]]) or glass by injecting them with a beam of high speed [[electrons]] from a linear electron beam accelerator (or [[Linear particle accelerator|Linac]], a type of [[particle accelerator]]).<ref>"Irradiation effects in Plexiglas" by Bernhard Gross, Journal of Polymer Science, Volume 27, Issue 115, Pages 135-143, 1958</ref> Inside the Linac, electrons are focused and accelerated to form a beam of high speed particles. Electrons emerging from the accelerator have energies up to 25MeV and are moving at an appreciable fraction (95 - 99+ percent) of the [[speed of light]] ([[special relativity|relativistic]] velocities).
If the electron beam is aimed towards a thick acrylic specimen, the electrons easily penetrate the surface of the acrylic, rapidly decelerating as they collide with molecules inside the plastic, finally coming to rest deep inside the specimen. Since acrylic is an excellent electrical insulator, these electrons become temporarily trapped within the specimen, forming a plane of excess negative charge. Under continued irradiation, the amount of trapped charge builds, until the effective voltage inside the specimen reaches millions of volts.<ref>"High Potentials in Electron-Irradiated Dielectrics" by Bernhard Gross and Sam V. Nablo, Journal of Applied Physics, April 1967, Volume 38, Issue 5, pages 2272-2275</ref> Once the electrical stress exceeds the [[dielectric strength]] of the plastic, some portions suddenly become conductive in a process called [[electrical breakdown#Failure of electrical insulation|dielectric breakdown]].
During breakdown, branching tree or fern-like conductive channels rapidly form and propagate through the plastic, allowing the trapped charge to suddenly rush out in a miniature [[lightning]]-like flash and bang. Breakdown of a charged specimen may also be manually triggered by poking the plastic with a pointed conductive object to create a point of excessive voltage stress. During the discharge, the powerful [[electric spark]]s leave thousands of branching chains of fractures behind - creating a permanent Lichtenberg figure inside the specimen. Although the internal charge within the specimen is negative, the discharge is initiated from the positively charged exterior surfaces of the specimen, so that the resulting discharge creates a positive Lichtenberg figure. These objects are sometimes called '''electron trees''', '''beam trees''', or '''lightning trees'''.
As the electrons rapidly decelerate inside the acrylic, they also generate powerful [[X-rays]]. Residual electrons and X-rays darken the acrylic by introducing defects (color centers) in a process called [[Solarisation (physics)|solarization]]. Solarization initially turns acrylic specimens a lime green color which then changes to an amber color after the specimen has been discharged. The color usually fades over time, and gentle heating, combined with oxygen, accelerates the fading process.<ref>"Radiation-induced changes in the index of refraction, density, and dielectric constant of poly(methyl methacrylate)" by Donald G. Gardner and Mohammad T. A. Toosi, Journal of Applied Polymer Science, Volume 11, Issue 7, July 1967, Pages 1065-1078</ref>
== On wood == [[File:Leopardwood 9 x 24.jpg|thumb|320x320px|Lichtenberg branching figure in [[leopardwood]]]] Lichtenberg figures can also be produced on wood. The types of wood and grain patterns affect the shape of the Lichtenberg Figure produced.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wH4Vlfv-klQ</ref>
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Brownian tree]] * [[Crown shyness]] * [[Dielectric breakdown model]] * [[Kirlian photography]] * [[Lightning burn]] * [[Patterns in nature]] {{div col end}}

'''Medway Community Forest Coop Ltd.''' is a [[Community forestry|community forest]] pilot project in southwestern [[Nova Scotia]]. Covering 15,000 hectares of land, it is the first community-owned forest on [[crown land]] in Canada east of [[Quebec]].
It borders the [[Kejimkujik National Park]] and the [[Tobeatic Game Reserve|Tobeatic Wilderness Area]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://novascotia.ca/natr/forestry/community-forest/medway.asp|title=Community Forests - Medway Community Forest {{!}} novascotia.ca|website=novascotia.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>.
== History == The provincial government bought private lands in southwestern Nova Scotia belonging to [[Resolute Forest Products]] in 2012<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/province-buys-bowater-lands-1.1186704|title=Province buys Bowater lands {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en-US}}</ref>. At the same time, community forestry in Nova Scotia quickly picked up steam after a discussion paper was published by Dalhousie University<ref>{{Cite book|chapter-url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=aufIDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA174&dq=community+forests+in+canada&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj5g_Pv7ffdAhVPuVkKHZLxDV0Q6AEIMTAB#v=onepage&q=community%20forests%20in%20canada&f=false|title=Community Forestry in Canada. Lessons from Policy and Practice.|last=Beckley|first=Thomas|publisher=UBC Press|year=2016|isbn=9780774831895|editor-last=Teitelbaum|editor-first=Sara|location=Vancouver|pages=62–63|chapter=Community Forestry in the Maritimes}}</ref>. In 2013, the government launched two calls for proposals of a community project pilot and Medway Community Forest was accepted. After some negotiations, the agreement was signed in January 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://novascotia.ca/News/Release/?id=20150130004|title=Community Forest Pilot Project Begins|last=Scotia|first=Communications Nova|website=News Releases|language=en|access-date=2018-10-08|date=2018-05-11}}</ref>.
The community forest commissioned a report in 2017 for the establishment of a carbon offset program in a [[Emissions trading|cap and trade]] system<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.medwaycommunityforest.com/summary-crown-carbon-report/crown-and-carbon-report/|title=Crown and Carbon Report - Medway Community Forest Co-op|work=Medway Community Forest Co-op|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en-US}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Use British English|date=July 2013|reason=See the UK section in the "Electric car use by country" article for more recent figures}}
[[File:PEV Registrations UK 2011 2014.png|thumb|350px|Registration of plug-in electric vehicles in the UK between January 2011 and December 2017<ref name=UKsales2011/><ref name=UKsales2012/><ref name=UK2013/><ref name=UK2014>{{cite web|url=http://www.smmt.co.uk/2015/01/december-2014-ev-registrations/|title=December 2014 – EV registrations|author=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]](SMMT)|publisher=SMT|date=2015-01-07|accessdate=2015-01-27}} ''A total of 14,518 plug-in electric cars were registered during 2014, consisting of 6,697 pure electrics and 7,821 plug-in hybrids, up from 3,586 plug-in electric cars were registered in 2013. A total of 2,476,435 new cars were registered in 2014''.</ref><ref name=UK2015>{{cite web|url=http://www.smmt.co.uk/2016/01/december-2015-ev-registrations/ |title=December 2015 – EV registrations|author=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]](SMMT)|publisher=SMT|date=2016-01-07|accessdate=2016-01-21}} ''A total of 28,188 plug-in electric cars were registered during 2015, consisting of 9,934 pure electrics and 18,254 plug-in hybrids. A total of 2,633,503 new cars were registered in 2015. There have been 47,690 cars registered eligible to the Plug-In Car Grant''.</ref><ref name=UK2016>{{cite web | url=https://www.smmt.co.uk/2017/01/december-2016-ev-registrations/ | title=December 2016 – EV registrations |author=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]](SMMT)|publisher=SMT| date=2017-01-05 | accessdate=2017-01-09}} ''Registrations in 2016 totaled 36,907 plug-in electric vehicles consisting of 10,264 all-electric cars and 26,643 plug-in hybrids. Of these, a total of 35,447 cars were eligible for the Plug-in Car Grant. Since its launch in 2011, a total of 83,052 cars eligible for the PICG have been registered through December 2016. A total of 2,692,786 new cars were registered in 2016, resulting in a plug-in electric car market share of 1.37% of new car sales.''</ref><ref name=UK2017>{{cite web | url=https://www.smmt.co.uk/2018/01/december-ev-registrations/ | title=December – EV registrations |author=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]] (SMMT)|publisher=SMMT| date=2018-01-05 | accessdate=2018-01-11}}''Registrations in 2017 totaled 47,263 plug-in electric vehicles consisting of 13,597 all-electric cars and 33,6663 plug-in hybrids. Of these, a total of 45,187 cars were eligible for the Plug-in Car Grant. Since its launch in 2011, a total of 127,509 cars eligible for the PICG have been registered through December 2017. A total of 2,540,617 new cars were registered in 2017, resulting in a plug-in electric car market share of 1.86% of new car sales.''</ref>]]
The adoption of '''plug-in electric vehicles in the United Kingdom''' is actively supported by the British government through the plug-in car and van grants schemes and other incentives.<ref name=FT112013/> More than 137,000 light-duty [[plug-in electric vehicle]]s had been registered in the UK as of December 2017.<ref name=UKStats>{{cite web |url=http://www.nextgreencar.com/electric-cars/statistics/ |title=Electric car market statistics |first=Ben |last=Lane |publisher=Next Green Car |location=UK |date=January 2018 |accessdate=2018-01-11}} ''{{As of|2017|12|31}}, the total UK light-duty electric fleet totals 137,100 plug-in electric vehicles, consisting of about 132,000 plug-in cars and 5,100 plug-in electric commercial vans. This figure includes a significant number of registered plug-in electric cars and vans which were not eligible for the grant schemes.''</ref> {{As of|2016|12}}, the British plug-in fleet was the fourth largest in Europe.<ref name=Global2mi/> The stock of plug-ins includes about 5,100 plug-in commercial vans. These figures include a significant number of registered plug-in electric cars and vans which were not eligible for the grant schemes.<ref name=UKStats/> The UK ranked in 2016 as the second best-selling European market after Norway, with almost 37,000 plug-in cars registered.<ref name=TopTen2016/>
There was a surge of plug-in car sales in Britain during 2014 and the following years: total registrations were 3,586 in 2013, but 36,907 plug-in electric cars were registered in 2016, 1.37% of total UK new car registrations.<ref name=UK2016/> Plug-in car sales in March 2017 achieved the best monthly plug-in registration volume on record ever with over 8,000 units,<ref name=UK032017/><ref name=UKrecord032017/> and registrations during the first quarter of 2017 achieved a record 1.47% market share of new car sales during this quarter.<ref name=UK032017>{{cite web | url=https://www.smmt.co.uk/2017/04/march-2017-ev-registrations/ | title=March 2017 – EV registrations |author=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]] (SMMT)|publisher=SMMT| date=2017-04-05 | accessdate=2017-04-16 }}</ref>
The [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]] is the all-time top selling plug-in car in the UK with 26,600 units registered through December 2016, accounting for about 50% of all plug-in hybrid sold in the UK since 2010.<ref name=OutlanderUK2016/><ref name=OutlanderUK25K/> The [[Nissan Leaf]] ranks second and it is also the all-time top selling all-electric car with 15,000 units sold by September 2016.<ref name=LeafUK15K/> Ranking third is the [[BMW i3]] with 4,457 units, followed by the [[Renault Zoe]] with 4,339 units, both, registered at the end of June 2016.<ref name=UK2Q2016/>
The [[Plug-in Car Grant]] (PICG) programme started on 1 January 2011 and is available across the UK. The programme initially reduced the up-front cost of eligible cars by providing a 25% grant towards the cost of new plug-in cars capped at {{GBP|5,000}}.<ref name=GCC0210/><ref name=DfT>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/plug-in-car-grant/plug-in-car-grant-vehicles|title=Plug-in car grant eligibility guidance|publisher=[[Department for Transport]] |date=February 2015|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> The programme was extended in February 2012 to include plug-in [[van]]s. Van buyers can receive 20% - up to {{GBP|8000}} - off the cost of a plug-in van.<ref name=UKPIVan/> As plug-in car sales surged during 2014 and 2015, the PICG was extended until March 2018. The maximum grant was reduced to {{GBP|4,500}}, and the amount granted varies according to emission levels. The eligible ultra-low emission vehicles (ULEVs) must meet criteria in one of three categories depending on emission levels ({{CO2}} emissions bands between 50 and 75g/km) and zero-emission-capable mileage (minimum of {{Convert|10|mi|abbr=on}}). [[Fuel cell vehicle|Hydrogen fuel cell cars]] are now eligible for the grant. A price cap is in place for the extension for Category 2 and 3 models with a list price of more than {{GBP|60,000}}, which are no longer eligible for the grant.<ref name=Extension2018/><ref name=Extension2018_2/> {{As of|2017|12}}, a total of 127,509 eligible cars have been registered since the launch of the Plug-in Car Grant in 2011,<ref name=UK2017/> and, {{as of|2016|12|lc=y}}, the number of claims made through the Plug-in Van Grant scheme totaled 2,938 units since the launch of the programme in 2012.<ref name=UK4Q2016Van/> The Plug-In Van Grant scheme was extended in October 2016 to make electric trucks above 3.5 tonnes eligible for grants of up to {{GBP|20,000}}<ref name=UKtruck/> {{As of|2017|01|10}}, the UK had 11,837 public charging points at 4,237 locations, of which 2,173 were [[rapid charging|rapid charging points]] at 695 locations.<ref name=ZapMap/>
==Government support==
Speaking at the [[G8]] summit in 2008, British [[Prime Minister]] [[Gordon Brown]] announced plans for Britain to be at the forefront of a "green car revolution". Mr Brown suggested that by 2020 all new cars sold in Britain could be electric or hybrid vehicles producing less than {{convert|100|gCO2/km}}.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.eta.co.uk/Every-car-in-Sweden-electric-by-2030/node/11951|title=Every car in Sweden electric by 2030 |chapter=Electric cars in Britain|date=2009-04-01|accessdate=2009-04-12|publisher=[[Environmental Transport Association]]}}</ref> In preparation for the introduction of mass-produced electric vehicles to Britain's roads, trials of electric cars took place from 2009, with further trials in cities across the UK from 2010. Local councils were invited to submit bids to become Britain's first "green cities". One example is [[Glasgow]], where a Scottish consortium has been awarded more than {{GBP|1.8 million}} to run a pilot electric car scheme from 2009 to 2011.<ref name=gh0905>{{citation |title=Glasgow in the driving seat to take the lead in electric car revolution |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12386945.Glasgow_in_the_driving_seat_to_take_the_lead_in_electric_car_revolution/|last=Liew|first=Jonathan|accessdate=2015-10-17|date=2009-04-09|newspaper=[[Glasgow Herald]]}}</ref>
[[File:Acton Works MMB 02 Mitsubishi i-MiEV.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Mitsubishi i-MiEV]], part of London Streets fleet]]
London mayor [[Boris Johnson]] also announced plans in April 2009 to deliver 25,000 electric car-charging places across the capital by 2015, in order to make London the "electric car capital of Europe". His target is to get 100,000 electric vehicles on to London's streets. Mr Johnson has also pledged to convert at least 1,000 [[Greater London Authority]] fleet vehicles to electric by 2015.<ref name=gh0905/><ref name=London/> [[Transport for London]] also announced that all new taxis must be zero emissions capable by 2018.<ref name=London062014/> {{As of|2014|06}}, there were about 3,000 plug-in electric vehicles in London, 3% of the mayor's goal, up from 1,700 electric cars in January 2009. The city also has only 1,408 charging points in operation, of which, only 57% were used in the first quarter of 2014.<ref name=London062014>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-27955893|title=Only 3% of mayor's target met on electric vehicles|author= |work=[[BBC News]]|date=2014-06-22|accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref> {{As of|2015|10}}, [[Greater London]] postcode areas contain 8,000 electric vehicles according to the [[Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency]] (DVLA).<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.london.gov.uk/media/mayor-press-releases/2015/10/japanese-firm-hails-london-electric-car-capital|title=Japanese firm hails London ‘electric car’ capital|author=Greater London Authority|publisher=[[Greater London Authority]]|location=London|date=2015-10-15|accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref>
Nissan's [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]] plant — the largest car factory in the UK — was granted a {{GBP|20.7 million}} grant from the British government and up to {{GBP|220 million}} from the [[European Investment Bank]].<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8573724.stm|title=Nissan Leaf electric car to be built in Sunderland|publisher=BBC News|date=2010-03-18|accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allcarselectric.com/blog/1043590_third-factory-for-2011-nissan-leaf-production-is-smart-move-in-ev-production-war|title=Third Factory For 2011 Nissan Leaf Production Is Smart Move In EV Production War|publisher=AllCarsElectric.com|date=2010-03-19|accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/apr/09/5|date=9 April 2009|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2009-04-12 |title=North-east could become world leader in developing green cars|last=Smith|first=Mark}}</ref> Production of the [[Nissan Leaf]] at the [[City of Sunderland|Sunderland]] plant began in March 2013.<ref name=Leaf55K>{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2013/03/28/nissan-starts-2013-leaf-production-in-uk-ev-now-made-on-three-c/|title=Nissan starts 2013 Leaf production in UK, EV now made on three continents|author=Sebastian Blanco|publisher= autoblog Green |date=2013-03-28|accessdate=2013-03-28}} ''See Press Release.''</ref> The plant has the capacity to produce 60,000 lithium-ion batteries and 50,000 Leafs a year.<ref name=BBC/> The UK produced Leaf are sold only in Europe has an improved driving range, lower price and a more European design.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://europe.autonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20120412/ANE/120419963|title=Nissan Leaf EV to be restyled for European tastes|author=Nick Gibbs|work=[[Automotive News|Automotive News Europe]]|date=2012-04-12|accessdate=2012-04-13}}</ref> The price of the 2013 Leaf produced in Sunderland is lower than the model built in Japan,<ref name=IEVs032013>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/nissan-leaf-production-starts-at-3rd-assembly-plant-in-sunderland-uk-factory-video/ |title=Nissan LEAF Production Starts At 3rd Assembly Plant In Sunderland, UK (Factory Video)|author=Jay Cole|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2013-03-28|accessdate=2013-03-29}}</ref><ref name=FT012013>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/83937bd8-657d-11e2-a17b-00144feab49a.html#axzz2OtMdmJSJ|title=Nissan cuts price of all-electric Leaf|author=Chris Tighe |work=[[Financial Times]]|date=2013-01-23|accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref> and Nissan is offering a battery leasing option for the three trims produced at Sunderland, which further reduced the purchase price by {{GBP|5,000}}.<ref name=BLease01>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/nissan-to-offer-battery-lease-option-on-leaf-in-europe-complete-pricing-details-announced/|title=Nissan to Offer Battery Lease Option on LEAF in Europe; Complete Pricing Details Announced|author=Eric Loveday|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2013-04-11|accessdate=2013-04-13}}</ref><ref name=BLease02>{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2013/04/12/nissan-leaf-battery-lease-uk/|title=Nissan Leaf battery lease available in UK for £70 a month|author=Danny King |publisher= Autoblog Green |date=2013-04-12|accessdate=2013-04-13}}</ref>
[[File:Evolt Electric Vehicle Charing Point - Arbroath Harbour.JPG|thumb|upright|Public charging point in [[Arbroath|Arbroath Harbour]], [[Scotland]]]]
{{As of|2013|11}}, the UK government had pledged {{GBP|400 million}} to support the deployment of plug-in vehicles in the five years between March 2010 and March 2015. However, {{as of|2013|09|30|lc=y}}, only {{GBP|92 million}} had been spent and an additional of {{GBP|44 million}} had been committed for projects up to March 2015, of which, {{GBP|82 million}} were allocated for research and development; {{GBP|16 million}} on infrastructure such as public charging points; and {{GBP|25 million}} in consumer purchase incentives (Plug-in Car Grant). {{As of|2013|11}}, the UK has around 5,000 public charging points, of which, only 200 are quick chargers.<ref name=FT112013>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/df62a896-6566-11e3-a27d-00144feabdc0.html?siteedition=intl#axzz2nh6otuJD|title=Spending to encourage use of electric cars falls flat|author=Henry Foy|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=2013-12-15|accessdate=2013-12-17}}</ref> By April 2014 the UK was the leader in quick charging deployment in Europe, with 211 [[CHAdeMO]] charging stations available across the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/sweden-uk-driving-growth-chademo-chargers-europe-1117/|title=Sweden and UK Drive Growth Of CHAdeMO Chargers In Europe To 1,117|author=Mark Kane|publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=2013-04-22|accessdate=2014-04-28}}</ref>
As a result of lower than initially expected electric and plug-in hybrid vehicle sales, in January 2014 the UK government launched the "Go Ultra Low" national campaign in partnership with five of the largest manufacturers of plug-in electric vehicles, [[BMW]], [[Nissan]], [[Renault]], [[Toyota]] and [[Vauxhall]]. The campaign has a cost of {{GBP|2.5 million}} and its objective is to promote the benefits of electric and plug-in hybrid cars to buyers. The Government classifies any car emitting less than 75g/km of CO<sub>2</sub> as ultra-low emission. The British government also announced its commitment to invest {{GBP|9 million}} to install more rapid charge-points to make motorway journeys by electric car feasible. According to [[Nicholas Clegg]], [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]], “Our clear objective is to move the car fleet in this country to ultra low-emission vehicles by 2040 and to put money and policy money behind it."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/motoring/green-motoring/10607357/Government-commits-to-electric-cars.html|title=Government commits to electric cars|author=Nick Gibbs|work=[[The Telegraph (UK)]]|date=2014-01-31|accessdate=2014-02-21}}</ref>
In July 2014 [[Baroness Kramer]], [[Minister of State for Transport]], announced that all of the government’s fleets will be supplied with funding to introduce electric vehicles. The "Ultra Low Emission Vehicle Readiness Project", funded with {{GBP|5 million}}, is the first step towards making all government vehicles electrically powered. Central government fleets will benefit first, with plans to bring in over 150 plug-in cars and vans. The [[Government Car Service]], which presently has 85 vehicles used by ministers, will be the initial target with electric cars expected to be in operation by the third quarter 2014. A second phase is scheduled next to provide funds for the public sector in general to purchase more electric vehicles. Beneficiary agencies includes the [[National Health Service]], [[Community council|councils]] and police forces.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nextgreencar.com/news/6710/Govt-fleets-funded-to-introduce-EVs |title=Govt fleets funded to introduce EVs|author=Edward Wirgman|work=Next Green Car|date=2014-07-18|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref>
===Purchase incentives===
In January 2009, transport secretary Geoff Hoon said the British government would make {{GBP|250 million}} (~{{USD|375 million}}) available for consumer incentives to bring electric cars to market in the UK.<ref name="London">{{citation |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/apr/08/electric-cars-boris-johnson-london|date=2009-09-04|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2009-04-12|title=London mayor – 100,000 electric cars for capital|last=Jha|first=Alok}}</ref> The plug-in grant scheme was first announced in January 2009 by the Labour Government. The coalition government, led by [[David Cameron]], took office in May 2010 and confirmed their support of the grant on 28 July 2010. This confirmed that £43 million would be available for the first 15 months of the scheme, with the 2011 Spending Review confirming funding for the programme for the lifetime of the Parliament of around £300 million (~{{USD|450 million}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nds.coi.gov.uk/content/detail.aspx?NewsAreaId=2&ReleaseID=414706&SubjectId=16&AdvancedSearch=true|title=Green light to ultra low carbon car consumer incentive|publisher=[[Department for Transport]]|date=2010-07-28|accessdate=2011-07-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nds.coi.gov.uk/content/Detail.aspx?ReleaseID=414706&NewsAreaID=2|title=Transport Secretary Philip Hammond confirmed today that motorists will receive up to £5,000 towards purchase of an ultra-low carbon car from January 2011|publisher=[[Department for Transport]]|date=2010-07-28|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-10783287 |title=Electric car subsidy spared cuts by government |author=Richard Scott|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2010-07-27|accessdate=2011-07-21}}</ref>
Two subsidy programs were implemented, the Plug-in Car Grant, from January 2011, and the Plug-In Van Grant, from February 2012. Both offer buyers of eligible vehicles a purchase subsidy discounted at the point of purchase. {{As of|2017|12}}, the number of eligible registered plug-in electric cars that have benefited with the subsidy totaled 127,509 units since the launch of the programme in 2011.<ref name=UK2017/> {{As of|2016|12}}, the number of claims made through the Plug-in Van Grant scheme totaled 2,938 units since the launch of the programme in 2012.<ref name=UK4Q2016Van/> {{As of|2014|12}}, there were 1,467 electric cars and vans registered which were not eligible for the Plug-in Grant scheme.<ref name=UK24K/>
==== Plug-in Car Grant ==== {{See also|Plug-in Car Grant}} The [[Plug-in Car Grant]] programme started on 1 January 2011 and is available across the [[United Kingdom|UK]] The programme reduces the up-front cost of eligible cars by providing a 25% grant towards the cost of new plug-in cars capped at {{GBP|5,000}} ({{USD|7,450}}).<ref name=GCC0210/><ref name=DfT/> From 1 April 2015, the purchase price cap was raised to cover up to 35% discount of the vehicle’s recommended retail price, up to the already existing £5,000 limit. This change means electric cars priced under {{GBP|20,000}}, such as the [[Renault Zoe]], are able to take advantage of most or all of the £5,000 discount.<ref name=Grant2015>{{cite web|url=https://transportevolved.com/2015/02/13/uk-government-announces-changes-plug-car-incentives-introduces-banding-based-zev-capabilities/|title=UK Government Announces Changes to Plug-in Car Incentives, Introduces Banding Based on ZEV Capabilities|author=Nikki Gordon-Bloomfield|publisher=Transport Evolved|date=2015-02-13|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> Both private and business fleet buyers are eligible for this grant which is received at the point of purchase.<ref name=GCC0210/>
[[File:2014 Vauxhall Ampera Positiv CVT 1.4 Front.jpg|thumb|The [[Vauxhall Ampera]] [[plug-in hybrid]] is eligible for the [[Plug-in Car Grant]] scheme.]]
The subsidy programme is managed in a similar way to the grant made as part of the 2009 [[Vehicle scrappage scheme (United Kingdom)|Car Scrappage Scheme]], allowing consumers to buy an eligible car discounted at the point of purchase with the subsidy claimed back by the manufacturer afterwards.<ref name=GCC0210>{{cite news|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/02/uk-ev-20100226.html|title=UK Government Announces £5,000 Grants Towards Purchase of Electric Drive Vehicles and First "Plugged-in Places"|publisher=Green Car Congress|date=2010-02-26|accessdate=2010-05-15}}</ref><ref name=DfT/> The government announced in April 2014 that funding for the full grant of up to {{GBP|5000}} will remain in place until either 50,000 grants have been issued or 2017, whichever is first.<ref name=Grant2015/><ref name=UKGrant25K>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/take-up-of-plug-in-car-grant-continues-to-rise|title=Take-up of plug-in car grant continues to rise - Number of ultra-low emission vehicles breaks 25,000 barrier.|author=[[Department for Transport]], Office for Low Emission Vehicles and Baroness Krame|publisher=UK Government|date=2015-02-13|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref> Nevertheless, as forecasts estimated that the scheme would reached its 50,000 limit around November 2015, the government announced in August 2015 that the Plug-in Car Grant should continue until at least February 2016 for all plug-in cars with {{CO2}} emissions of 75 g/km of under.<ref name=GrantExtended/> The Government also announced that a minimum of {{GBP|200 million}} (~{{USD|300 million}}) has been made available to continue the Plug-in Car Grant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2015/08/20150826-uk.html|title=UK extends current levels of the Plug-in Car Grant to at least February 2016 |publisher=Green Car Congress|author=Mike Millikin|date=2015-08-26|accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref>
Vehicles eligible for the subsidy must meet the following criteria:<ref name=GCC0210/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://assets.dft.gov.uk/eligibility-criteria-summary.pdf|title=Summary of the Plug-in Car Grant Eligibility Criteria|publisher=[[Department for Transport]]|accessdate=2011-07-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328012159/http://assets.dft.gov.uk/eligibility-criteria-summary.pdf|archivedate=28 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * Vehicle type: Only [[Ultra Low Emission Vehicle|ultra-low emission cars]] are eligible ([[Directive 2001/116/EC#Vehicle categories|vehicle category M1]]). Motorbikes, quadricycles and vans are not covered. * [[Carbon dioxide emission|Carbon dioxide exhaust emissions]]: Vehicles must emit equal or less than 75 [[g/km|grams of carbon dioxide (CO2) per kilometre]] driven. * Range: [[Electric vehicle]]s (EVs) must be able to travel a minimum of {{Convert|70|mi|abbr=on}} between charges. [[Plug-in hybrid electric vehicle]]s (PHEVs) must have a minimum [[all-electric range]] of {{Convert|10|mi|abbr=on}}. * Minimum top speed: Vehicles must be able to reach a speed of {{Convert|60|mph|abbr=on}} or more. * Warranty: Vehicles must have a 3-year or {{Convert|60,000|mi}} vehicle warranty (guarantee) and a 3-year battery and electric drive train warranty, with the option of extending the battery warranty for an extra 2 years(‘drive train’ means the parts that send power from the engine to the wheels. These include the clutch, transmission (gear box), drive shafts, U-joints and differential). * Battery performance: Vehicles must have either a minimum 5-year warranty on the battery and electric drive train as standard, or extra evidence of battery performance to show reasonable performance after 3 years of use * Electrical safety: Vehicles must comply with certain regulations (UN-ECE Reg 100.00) that show that they are electrically safe. * Crash safety: To make sure cars will be safe in a crash, they must either have: EC whole vehicle type approval (EC WVTA, not small series) or evidence that the car has appropriate levels of safety as judged by international standards
In February 2015 the government announced that to take account of rapidly developing technology, and the growing range of ultra-low emission vehicles (ULEVs) on the British market, the criteria for the plug-in car grant was updated and from April 2015, eligible ULEVs must meet criteria in one of the following categories depending on emission levels and zero-emission-capable mileage, with a technology neutral approach, which means that [[fuel cell vehicle|hydrogen fuel cell cars]] are also eligible for the grant:<ref name=DfT/><ref name=Grant2015/> * Category 1: {{CO2}} emissions of less than 50g/km and a zero emission range of at least {{Convert|70|mi|abbr=on}}. * Category 2: {{CO2}} emissions of less than 50g/km and a zero emission range between {{Convert|10|to|69|mi|abbr=on}}. * Category 3: {{CO2}} emissions of 50-75g/km and a zero emission range of at least {{Convert|20|mi|abbr=on}}.
{{As of|2016|10}}, the following 31 cars available in the British market are eligible for the grant according to their category:<ref name=UKGrantEligible>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/plug-in-car-van-grants/eligibility|title=Plug-in car and van grants - Eligible vehicles by category |author=UK Government|publisher=UK Government|date=2016-10-25 | accessdate=2016-10-29}}</ref>
;Eligible category 1 vehicles [[BMW i3]], [[BYD e6]], [[Citroen C-Zero]], [[Ford Focus Electric]], [[Hyundai Ioniq Electric]], [[Kia Soul EV]], [[Mahindra e2o]], [[Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive]], [[Nissan e-NV200|Nissan e-NV200 5- and 7-seater Combi]], [[Nissan Leaf]], [[Peugeot iOn]], [[Renault Fluence Z.E.]], [[Renault Zoe]], [[Smart Fortwo electric drive]], [[Tesla Model S]], [[Toyota Mirai]], [[Volkswagen e-Golf]], and [[Volkswagen e-Up!]].
[[File:2016 BMW i8.jpg|thumb|[[Plug-in hybrid]] models with a list price of over {{GBP|60000}}, such as the [[BMW i8]], are no longer eligible for the Plug-in Car Grant from March 2016.<ref name=UKGrantEligible/><ref name=Extension2018_3/>]]
;Eligible category 2 vehicles [[Audi A3 e-tron]] (MY 2016 only), [[BMW 2 Series|BMW 225xe]], [[BMW 3 Series|BMW 330e]], [[Kia Optima PHEV]], [[Mercedes-Benz C-Class (W205)#C350 e Plug-in Hybrid (2015-)|Mercedes-Benz C350 e]], [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]] (except GX3h 4Work), [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]], [[Volkswagen Golf GTE]], [[Volkswagen Passat GTE]], [[Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid]] (D5 and D6 Twin Engine), and [[Volvo XC90 T8|Volvo XC90 T8 Twin Engine Momentum]].<ref name=UKGrantEligible/>
;Ineligible vehicles Category 2 or 3 vehicles with a recommended retail price over £60,000 aren’t eligible for a grant. This includes: [[BMW i8]] (category 2), [[Mercedes-Benz S500 Plug-in Hybrid]] (category 3), and [[Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid]] (category 3).<ref name=UKGrantEligible/>
The [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Tesla Roadster]] was not included in the government's list of eligible vehicles for the plug-in electric car grant. Tesla Motors stated that the company applied for the scheme, but did not complete its application.<ref name=TeslaUK>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2010/dec/14/tesla-roadster-electric-car-list|title=Why is the Tesla Roadster not on the government's electric car grant list?|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2010-12-14|accessdate=2011-07-21}}</ref>
In December 2015, the [[Department for Transport]] (DfT) announced that Plug-in car grant was extended until the end of March 2018 to encourage more than 100,000 UK motorists to buy cleaner vehicles. A total funding of {{GBP|400 million}} (~{{USD|600 million}}) will be available for the extension. The criteria for the Plug-in Car Grant was updated and the maximum grant drops from {{GBP|5,000}} (~{{USD|7,450}}) to {{GBP|4,500}} (~{{USD|6,750}}). For the extension, the amount of the grant is linked in directly with the Office for Low Emission Vehicles three vehicle categories issued in April 2015. The eligible ultra-low emission vehicles (ULEVs) must meet criteria in one of three categories depending on emission levels ({{CO2}} emissions bands between 50 and 75g/km) and zero-emission-capable mileage with a minimum [[all-electric range]] of {{Convert|10|mi|abbr=on}}. [[fuel cell vehicle|Hydrogen fuel cell cars]] are also eligible for the grant.<ref name=Grant2015/><ref name=Extension2018>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/dec/17/plug-in-car-grant-extended-to-2018 |title=Plug-in car grant extended to 2018|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2015-12-17|accessdate=2015-12-20}}</ref><ref name=Extension2018_2>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextgreencar.com/news/7409/extension-announced-for-plugin-car-grant/ |title=Extension announced for Plug-in Car Grant|author=Chris Lilly|publisher=Next Green Car|location=UK |date=2015-12-17|accessdate=2015-12-20}}</ref> The updated scheme went into effect on 1 March 2016.<ref name=Extension2018_2/>
[[File:Tesla Roadster.JPG|thumb|left|The [[electric car|all-electric]] [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Tesla Roadster]] was not included on the government's plug-in electric car grant list of eligible vehicles.<ref name=TeslaUK/>]]
A price cap is in place, with all Category 1 plug-in vehicles eligible for the full grant no matter what their purchase price, while Category 2 and 3 models with a list price of more than {{GBP|60000}} (~{{USD|90000}}) are no longer eligible for the grant. Vehicles with a zero-emission range of at least {{Convert|70|mi|abbr=on}} (category 1), including hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, get a full {{GBP|4,500}} (~{{USD|6,700}}), but plug-in hybrids (categories 2 and 3) costing under {{GBP|60000}} (~{{USD|90000}}) receive {{GBP|2500}} (~{{USD|3725}}).<ref name=Extension2018/><ref name=Extension2018_2/> Under the extended scheme, some plug-in hybrid sports car are no longer eligible for the grant, such as the [[BMW i8]] because of its {{GBP|100000}} (~{{USD|150,000}}) purchase price tag.<ref name=Extension2018_3>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/cars/article-3364184/Plug-car-grant-extended-plug-hybrid-buyers-receive-half-saving.html |title=Plug-in car grant extended to 2018 but hybrid buyers will now receive half as much as before towards new vehicles |author= Robert Hull |work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=2015-12-17|accessdate=2015-12-20}}</ref> The grant scheme will come under review when a cumulative total of 40,000 Category 1 claims, and 45,000 Category 2 and 3 combined sales have been made. Both these totals will include cars sold before March 2016.<ref name=Extension2018_2/>
In addition to the extension of the Plug-in Grant, the government also announced it will continue the "Electric Vehicle Homecharge Scheme." Starting in March 2016 owners of ultra-low emission vehicles who install a dedicated charge point at their home, covering roughly half the average cost, get {{GBP|500}} (~{{USD|750}}) towards the cost of installing the charging point, rather than the previous {{GBP|700}} (~{{USD|1050}}) maximum.<ref name=Extension2018/><ref name=Extension2018_2/>
==== Plug-in Van Grant ====
The Plug-In Car Grant was extended to include vans since February 2012. Van buyers can receive 20% - up to {{GBP|8,000}} (~ {{USD|12,000}}) - off the cost of a plug-in van. To be eligible for the scheme, vans have to meet performance criteria to ensure safety, range, and ultra-low tailpipe emissions.<ref name=UKPIVan>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/plug-in-van-grant|title=Plug-in Van Grant|author=[[Department for Transport]] (DfT)|publisher=DfT|date=2014-02-03|accessdate=2014-08-17}} ''{{As of|2013|06|30}}, 637 claims have been made through the plug-in van grant program.''</ref> Consumers, both business and private can receive the discount at the point of purchase.<ref name=UKPIVan/> The Plug-In Van Grant scheme was extended in October 2016 to make electric trucks above 3.5 tonnes eligible for grants of up to {{GBP|20,000}}, when businesses switch their large trucks to an electric vehicle.<ref name=UKtruck>{{cite web| url=http://www.investinuk.net/news/%C2%A34-million-boost-help-businesses-switch-vans-and-trucks-electric | title=£4 million boost to help businesses switch vans and trucks to electric | publisher=InvestInUK | date=October 2016 | accessdate=2016-10-29}}</ref> Also in October 2016, the government announced their commitment for an additional {{GBP|4 million}} to the scheme so that all vans and trucks meeting the eligibility requirements can benefit from the grant scheme.<ref name=UKtruck/> The extension of the Plug-In Van grant means that [[Large goods vehicle|N2 vans]] (3.5 – 12 tonnes gross weight) and [[Vehicle category#EU classification|N3 vans]] (over 12 tonnes gross weight) are now eligible.<ref name=UKtruck/>
[[File:Vito E-Cell trimmed.jpg|thumb|275px|The [[Mercedes-Benz Vito E-Cell]] is eligible for the Plug-In Van Grant.]]
The eligibility criteria for vans with a gross weight of 3.5 tonnes or less ([[Light commercial vehicle|N1 van]]) are:<ref name=UKPIVan/>
* Vehicle type: only new vans are eligible vehicle category N1. This includes pre-registration conversions (normal, internal combustion engine vans that were converted to battery or hybrid versions by specialist converters before the car’s first registration). * Carbon dioxide exhaust emissions: vehicles must emit less than 75 grams of carbon dioxide ({{CO2}}) per kilometre driven. * Range: eligible fully electric vans must be able to travel a minimum of {{Convert|60|mi|abbr=on}} between charges. Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs) must have a minimum electric range of {{Convert|10|mi|abbr=on}}. * Minimum top speed: vehicles must be able to reach a speed of {{convert|50|mi/h|abbr=on}} or more. * Warranty: Vehicles must have a 3-year or {{convert|60,000|mi|abbr=on}} vehicle warranty (guarantee) and a 3-year battery and electric drive train warranty, with the option of extending the battery warranty for an extra 2 years * Battery performance: vehicles must have either a minimum 5-year warranty on the battery and electric drive train as standard or extra evidence of battery performance to show reasonable performance after 3 years of use * Electrical safety: vehicles must comply with certain regulations (UN-ECE Reg 100.00) that show that they are electrically safe. * Crash safety To make sure cars will be safe in a crash, they must either have EC whole vehicle type approval (EC WVTA, not small series) or evidence that the car has appropriate levels of safety as judged by international standards.
{{As of|2016|12}}, the number of claims made through the Plug-in Van Grant scheme totaled 2,938 units since the launch of the programme in 2012, up from 1,906 made by the end of December 2015.<ref name=UK4Q2016Van>{{cite web | url=http://www.racfoundation.org/data/plug-in-van-grant-claims-data-page | title=Claims made through the Plug-in Van Grant scheme | author = RAC Foundation | publisher=[[RAC Foundation]]| location=UK | date=February 2017 | accessdate=2017-02-24}} ''See graph with PIVG cumulative claims and claims by quarter''.</ref> {{As of|2016|10}} the following nine vans are eligible for the grant: [[BD Otomotive eTraffic]], [[BD Otomotiv eDucato]], [[Peugeot ePartner|Citroën Berlingo]], [[Mercedes-Benz Vito E-Cell]], [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV|Mitsubishi Outlander GX3h 4Work]], [[Nissan e-NV200]], [[Peugeot ePartner]], [[Renault Kangoo Z.E.]], and [[Smith Electric Edison]].<ref name=UKGrantEligible/>
===Plugged-in Places===
On 19 November 2009, [[Andrew Adonis]], the [[Secretary of State for Transport]], announced a scheme called "Plugged-in-Places", making available £30 million to be shared between three and six cities to investigate further the viability of providing power supply for electric vehicles, and encouraging local government and business to participate and bid for funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.which.co.uk/news/2009/11/thousands-of-electric-car-charging-points-due-189176 |publisher=[[Which?]]|date=2009-11-20|accessdate=2009-11-22|title=Thousands of electric car charging points due}}</ref>
The Government is supporting the ‘Plugged-In Places’ programme to install vehicle recharging points across the UK. The scheme offers match-funding to consortia of businesses and public sector partners to support the installation of electric vehicle recharging infrastructure in lead places across the UK.<ref name=DfT2>{{cite web|url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/topics/sustainable/olev/recharging-electric-vehicles/|title=Recharging infrastructure|publisher=[[Department for Transport]] |date=|accessdate=2011-12-06}}</ref> There are eight Plugged-In Places: East of England;<ref>[http://www.sourceeast.net/]</ref> Greater Manchester; London;<ref>[https://www.sourcelondon.net/]</ref> Midlands;<ref>[http://www.cenex.co.uk/programmes/plugged-in-places the] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110825170205/http://www.cenex.co.uk/programmes/plugged-in-places |date=25 August 2011 }}</ref> Milton Keynes;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chargemasterplc.com/charging-schemes/milton-keynes/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316101205/http://chargemasterplc.com/charging-schemes/milton-keynes/ |archivedate=16 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> North East;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chargeyourcar.org.uk/indexx3.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316101204/http://www.chargeyourcar.org.uk/indexx3.php |archivedate=16 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Northern Ireland;<ref>[http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/ecar]</ref> and Scotland. The Government also published an Infrastructure Strategy in June 2011.<ref>[http://www.dft.gov.uk/publications/plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy Making the Connection: the Plug-In Vehicle Infrastructure Strategy]</ref>
===London congestion charge=== [[File:2017 Volkswagen Golf GTE S-A 1.4.jpg|thumb|The [[Volkswagen Golf GTE]] [[plug-in hybrid]] is exempted from the [[London congestion charge]].]]
[[Battery electric vehicles|All-electric vehicle]]s (BEVs) and eligible [[plug-in hybrid electric vehicle]]s (PHEVs) qualify for a 100% discount from the [[London congestion charge]]. A plug-in electric drive vehicle qualifies if the vehicle is registered with the [[Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency]] (DVLA) and has a fuel type of 'electric', or alternatively, if the vehicle is a 'plug-in hybrid' and is on the Government's list of PHEVs eligible for the OLEV grant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tfl.gov.uk/modes/driving/congestion-charge/discounts-and-exemptions?intcmp=4368|title=Discounts and exemptions - Ultra Low Emission Discount (ULED)|author=[[Transport for London]]|publisher=Transport for London |date=February 2015|accessdate=2015-02-15}} ''Click on "Ultra Low Emission Discount (ULED)" for details.''</ref> {{As of|2016|02}}, approved PHEVs include all extended-range cars such as the [[BMW i3 REx]], and plug-in hybrids that emit 75g/km or less of {{CO2}} and that meet the [[Euro 5]] standard for air quality, such as the [[Audi A3 Sportback e-tron]], [[BMW i8]], [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]] (passenger and van variants), [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]], and [[Volkswagen Golf GTE]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.goultralow.com/what-are-go-ultra-low-cars/types-of-vehicles/plug-in-hybrid/|title=Vehicle technologies - Plug-in hybrids|author=Go Ultra Low|publisher=Go Ultra Low|date=February 2016|accessdate=2016-02-03}}</ref>
The original Greener Vehicle Discount was substituted by the Ultra Low Emission Discount (ULED) scheme that went into effect on 1 July 2013. The ULED introduced more stringent emission standards that limited the free access to the congestion charge zone to any car or van that emits 75g/km or less of CO<sub>2</sub> and meets the [[Euro 5]] emission standards for air quality. {{As of|2013|07}} there are no [[internal combustion]]-only vehicles that meet this criteria. The measure is designed to limit the growing number of diesel vehicles on London's roads. Mayor Boris Johnson approved the new scheme in April 2013, after taking into account a number of comments received during the 12-week public consultation that took place. About 20,000 owners of vehicles registered for the Greener Vehicle Discount by June 2013 were granted a three-year [[Sunset provision|sunset period]] (until 24 June 2016) before they have to pay the full congestion charge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/04/uled-20130424.html|title=London to introduce new Ulta Low Emission Discount for Congestion Charge scheme; countering dieselization|author= |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=24 April 2013|accessdate=24 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/apr/24/pollution|title=London tightens up congestion charge in attempt to drive out diesel |author= |work=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 April 2013|accessdate=24 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thegreencarwebsite.co.uk/blog/index.php/2013/07/01/london-tightens-congestion-charge-exemptions/|title=London tightens Congestion Charge exemptions |author=Faye Sunderland|publisher=The Green Car Website (UK)|date=1 July 2013|accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-23125082|title=New green discount for the congestion charge comes in|author= |work=[[BBC News]]|date=2013-07-01|accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>
==Field testing programmes== Field testing with 100 [[Smart ED]]s began in London in 2007.<ref name=GCC0610>{{Cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/06/smartus-20100609.html#more|title=smart fortwo electric drive Debuts in the US|publisher= Green Car Congress |date=2010-06-09|accessdate=2010-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2009/mar/21/smart-fortwo-ed|title=Smart Fortwo Ed: Is the future a Smart one?|author=Andrew Anthony|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=2009-03-21|accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> On 30 April 2009, the [[Electric Car Corporation]] put on sale the [[Citroën C1 ev'ie]], an adapted [[Citroën C1]] intended for city driving. On that date, it had a list price of £16,850 ($24,989 US).<ref name=times-notready>{{citation |newspaper=[[The Times]] |title=Electric Citroën C1 car is ready, but government grants are not |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/transport/article6194754.ece |last=Webster|first=Ben |date=30 April 2009 |accessdate=2009-04-30 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/beds/bucks/herts/8026380.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Four-seater electric car unveiled |date=30 April 2009 |accessdate=2009-04-13 }}</ref><ref>{{citation |newspaper=[[Autocar (magazine)|Autocar]] |date=30 April 2009 |title=Car Reviews - First Drive |accessdate=2009-04-30 |url=http://www.autocar.co.uk/CarReviews/FirstDrives/ECC-C1-Ev%27ie-30kw/239834/ |last=Parrott|first=Vicky }}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=The Electric Car Corporation Launches the Citroën C1 ev'ie - The UK's First 4 Seat All-Electric Production Car |url=http://www.theautochannel.com/news/2009/04/29/458863.html |newspaper=theautochannel.com |date=30 April 2009 |accessdate=2009-04-30 }}</ref> [[File:An Electric MINI - geograph.org.uk - 1710621.jpg|thumb|left|Mini E recharging in the UK]] A demonstration trial with the [[Mini E]] took place between December 2009 and March 2011 with 40 Mini E cars leased to private users for a two consecutive six-month field trial periods.<ref name=GCCUK11>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/08/minie-20110805.html|title=BMW Group releases results of UK-supported EV trial|publisher= Green Car Congress |date=2011-08-05|accessdate=2011-08-08}}</ref> In addition, one Mini E was delivered to the Government car pool in [[Downing Street]] to be tested by ministers in an urban environment on their official business around London.<ref name=Brookes1209/> The UK trial was a partnership between BMW Group UK, [[Scottish and Southern Energy]], the [[South East England Development Agency]] (SEEDA), [[Oxford City Council]] and [[Oxfordshire County Council]]. Data collection and research was conducted by [[Oxford Brookes University]]’s Sustainable Vehicle Engineering Centre throughout the UK project. Funding support was provided by the [[Technology Strategy Board]] and the [[Department for Transport]] (DFT) as part of the {{GBP|25 million}} ({{USD|41 million}}) UK-wide program involving trials of 340 ultra-low carbon vehicles from several carmakers.<ref name=GCCUK11/><ref name=Brookes1209>{{cite web|url=http://www.brookes.ac.uk/about/news/mini-e-with-pm|title=Prime Minister backs MINI E trials|publisher=[[Oxford Brookes University]]|date=2009-12-16|accessdate=2010-06-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712225040/http://www.brookes.ac.uk/about/news/mini-e-with-pm|archivedate=12 July 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=GCC1209>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/12/minie-20091214.html|title=BMW Delivers 40 Electric MINI E Cars for UK Trial|publisher= Green Car Congress |date=2009-12-14|accessdate=2009-12-25}}</ref> The selected test area is roughly a triangle contained within the [[M40 motorway]] between the [[M25 motorway]] and [[Oxford]], the [[A34 road|A34]] south to the [[M3 motorway (Great Britain)|M3 motorway]], and the M3 back to the M25.<ref name=Telegraph1009>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/motoring/green-motoring/6452749/MINI-E-review.html|title=MINI E review: The all-electric version of the MINI is being trialled in Britain|author=Anthony ffrench-Constant|publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=2009-10-29|accessdate=2010-06-18}}</ref>
The 40 Mini E electric cars were kept in use after the trial was completed in March 2011, participating in activities to promote awareness and understanding of electric vehicles. These cars were part of the BMW Group UK’s official vehicle fleet of 4,000 low-emission luxury vehicles deployed for the [[2012 Summer Olympics|London 2012 Olympic Games]]. The fleet also included 160 [[BMW ActiveE]] electric cars.<ref name=GCCUK11/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1074476_bmws-low-emissions-olympic-fleet-lands-in-london|title=BMW's Low-Emissions Olympic Fleet Lands In London|author=Antony Ingram|work=Motor Authority|date=2012-03-26|accessdate=2012-03-26}}</ref> {{Clear}}
==Charging infrastructure==
[[File:Electric car charging in Westminster April 2008.jpg|thumb|The [[REVAi|REVAi/G-Wiz i]] electric car charging at an on-street station in [[London]]]] {{As of|2017|01|10}}, the UK had 11,837 public charging points at 4,237 locations, of which 2,173 were [[rapid charging|rapid charging points]] at 695 locations.<ref name=ZapMap>{{Cite web|title = Charging point statistics 2017 | url = https://www.zap-map.com/statistics/ | website = Zap-Map | date=2017-01-10 | accessdate = 2017-01-10}}</ref> According to [http://www.national-charge-point-registry.uk/ UK's National Chargepoint Registry], there are over 25 network operators (charge point owners, branded networks, such as [[Chargemaster Plc#POLAR public charging network|POLAR]] and charge point controllers, such as [[Chargemaster Plc|Chargemaster]]) at a national and regional basis.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.national-charge-point-registry.uk/network-activity/|title=NCR Statistics: Activity by Network|last=|first=|date=2017-09-06|website=National Chargepoint Registry UK|access-date=2017-09-06}}</ref> {{As of|2016|10}}, the regions with most of the infrastructure are [[London]] (16%), [[South East England|South East]] (15.6%), [[Scotland]] (15.1%), [[South West England|South West]] (9.1%), and [[North East England|North East]] (8.7%).<ref name=ZapMap/>
The UK also has nine regional operators:<ref>{{Cite web|title = Public charging networks - Plugged-in Places - Electric cars|url = https://www.zap-map.com/charge-points/public-charging-point-networks/|website = Zap-Map|accessdate = 2015-10-15}}</ref> [[Source London]], [[Source East]], [[Source West]], [[ChargePlace Scotland]], [[Energise]] (for the South-East), [[Plugged-In Midlands]], [[Greater Manchester EV]], [[ChargerNet]] (for Bournemouth, Dorset and Poole) and [[eCar]] (for Northern Ireland).
Many companies, local and regional authorise also provide charging to employees and members of the public. Purchasers of electric vehicles also receive a subsidy of up to £500 towards the installation of a charger at their home (which covers nearly all purchase and installation costs).<ref>{{Cite web|title = Grant schemes for electric vehicle charging infrastructure|url = https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/government-grants-for-low-emission-vehicles|website = GOV.UK|accessdate = 2017-07-28}}</ref>
==Sales== [[File:Top PEV global markets stock 2017 final with California.png|thumb|325px |Cumulative light-duty plug-in electric vehicle sales in the UK compared to the world's top-selling countries and regional markets {{as of|2017|12|lc=y}}. The UK is the third largest European plug-in market.<ref name=UKStats/><ref name=Global2mi>{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/the-world-just-bought-its-two-millionth-plug-in-car/ |title=The World Just Bought Its Two-Millionth Plug-in Car | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | work= HybridCars.com | date=2017-01-16 |accessdate=2017-01-17}} ''An estimated 2,032,000 highway-legal plug-in passenger cars and vans have been sold worldwide at the end of 2016. The top selling markets are China (645,708 new energy cars, including imports), Europe (638,000 plug-in cars and vans), and the United States (570,187 plug-in cars). The top European country markets are Norway (135,276), the Netherlands (113,636), France (108,065), and the UK (91,000). Total Chinese sales of domestically produced new energy vehicles, including buses and truck, totaled 951,447 vehicles. China was the top selling plug-in car market in 2016, and also has the world's largest stock of plug-in electric cars.''</ref>]]
More than 137,000 light-duty plug-in electric vehicles have been registered in the UK up until December 2017, including about 5,100 plug-in commercial vans.<ref name=UKStats>{{cite web |url=http://www.nextgreencar.com/electric-cars/statistics/ |title=Electric car market statistics |first=Ben |last=Lane |publisher=Next Green Car |location=UK |date=January 2018 |accessdate=2018-01-11}} ''{{As of|2017|12|31}}, the total UK light-duty electric fleet totals 137,100 plug-in electric vehicles, consisting of about 132,000 plug-in cars and 5,100 plug-in electric commercial vans. This figure includes a significant number of registered plug-in electric cars and vans which were not eligible for the grant schemes.''</ref> These figures includes a significant number of registered plug-in electric cars and vans which were not eligible for the grant schemes.<ref name=UKStats/> Before the market launch of highway-capable [[mass production]] plug-in electric cars in 2010, a total of 1,096 electric vehicles were registered in the country between 2006 and December 2010.<ref name=UK2006_10>{{cite web|url=http://www.smmt.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/Motor-Industry-Facts-2011.pdf|title=Motor Industry Facts 2011|author=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]] (SMMT) |publisher=SMMT|date=April 2011|accessdate=2012-01-14}} ''Download the pdf report. === 2014 ===
The British market experienced a rapid growth of plug-in car sales during 2014, driven by the introduction of new models such as the [[BMW i3]], [[Tesla Model S]], [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]], [[Renault Zoe]], and [[Volkswagen e-Up!]].<ref name=UK092014>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/oct/07/uk-electric-car-sales-surge-in-2014|title=UK electric car sales surge in 2014|author=Will Nichols|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2014-10-07|accessdate=2014-10-09}}</ref><ref name=UK24K/><ref name=UKSales2014/> The number of plug-in cars available in the market climbed from 9 models in 2011 to 18 in 2013, and to 29 models by the end of 2014.<ref name=UK24K>{{cite web|url = http://www.nextgreencar.com/news/6910/UK-electric-fleet-passes-24500-mark|title = UK electric fleet passes 24,500 mark|author = Ben Lane|publisher = Next Green Car|location = UK|date = 2015-01-12|accessdate = 2015-01-19}}</ref> Registrations during 2014 totaled 14,518 plug-in electric cars and consisted of 6,697 pure electrics and 7,821 plug-in hybrids. Total registrations in 2014 were up 305% from 2013, with all-electric cars growing 167% while plug-in hybrid registrations were up 628% from a year earlier.<ref name=UK2014/> The plug-in electric car segment captured a 0.59% market share of new car sales in 2014, over three times and a half the market share of 2013 (0.16%).<ref name=UK2014/><ref name=UKSales122013/> In November 2014, with 646 all-electric cars and 1,225 plug-in hybrids registered, the segment's market share passed 1% of monthly new car sales for the first time in the UK.<ref name=UKsales112014>{{cite web|url=http://www.smmt.co.uk/2014/12/november-2014-ev-registrations/|title=November 2014 – EV registrations|author=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]](SMMT)|publisher=SMMT|date=2014-12-04|accessdate=2014-12-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/plug-in-electric-car-sales-uk-at-1-of-market-in-november/|title=Plug-In Electric Car Sales UK At 1% Of Market In November |author=Mark Kane|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2014-12-08|accessdate=2014-12-09}}</ref> Again in January 2015, the segment's market share was over 1% of new car sales with 1,715 plug-in electric cars registered that month.<ref name=UK012015>{{cite web|url=http://www.smmt.co.uk/2015/02/january-2015-ev-registrations/|title=January 2015 – EV registrations|author=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]](SMMT)|publisher=SMT|date=2015-02-05|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/uk-plug-in-electric-car-sales-begin-2015-at-over-1-market-share/|title=UK Plug-in Electric Car Sales Begin 2015 At Over 1% Market Share|author=Mark Kane|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2015-02-13|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref>
[[File:West Midlands Police Nissan LEAF.jpg|thumb|Nissan Leaf patrol cars deployed by the [[West Midlands Police]], England.
