15 March 2002 (official launch) |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = |headquarters = [[Washington, DC]] |employees = 500 (2012) |budget = |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |parent_agency = [[World Bank]] |child1_agency = |slogan = |website = [http://www.worldbank.org/ World Bank] |footnotes = }} The '''World Bank, Chennai''' is the extension of the [[World Bank]] headquartered in [[Washington, DC]]. The World Bank Chennai office offers corporate financial, accounting, administrative and IT services for the Bank's offices in around 150 countries.{{cite news | last = Padmanabhan | first = Mukund | coauthors = | title = Chennai chosen for World Bank back office | newspaper = The Hindu | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = The Hindu | date = 6 March 2002 | url = http://www.hindu.com/2002/03/06/stories/2002030603070100.htm | accessdate = 21 Oct 2012}}{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = World Bank chief visits Chennai office | newspaper = ZeeNews India.com | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = ZeeNews.com | date = 29 March 2012 | url = http://zeenews.india.com/business/news/economy/world-bank-chief-visits-chennai-office_44889.html | accessdate = 9 Oct 2012}} The Chennai office handles several value-added operations of the bank that were earlier handled only in its Washington, DC office. ==History== The Chennai office started its business operation as a primary processing work, including payroll processing, in August 2001 with 80 staff.{{cite news | last = Radhakrishnan | first = R. K. | coauthors = | title = World Bank decides to locate back office in Chennai | newspaper = The Hindu | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = The Hindu | date = 26 May 2009 | url = http://www.hindu.com/2009/05/26/stories/2009052660290800.htm | accessdate = 10 Oct 2012}} On 15 March 2002, the chief minister of Tamil Nadu, J. Jayalalithaa, inaugurated a new 26,000 sq ft office in Raheja Towers in Anna Salai, where the bank started functioning in a full-fledged manner to process all of the bank's accounting functions and its global payrolls, with about 90 personnel.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = World Bank opens office in Chennai news | newspaper = Domain-b.com | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = Domain-b.com | date = 16 March 2002 | url = http://www.domain-b.com/finance/banks/world_bank/20020316_office.html | accessdate = 10 Oct 2012}} The same year, the staff strength increased to about 180.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = World Bank to build own office space in Chennai | newspaper = Business Line | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = The Hindu | date = 18 November 2003 | url = http://www.thehindubusinessline.in/2003/11/18/stories/2003111801351700.htm | accessdate = 31 Jul 2012}} In 2003, the bank decided to move the analytical work in bond valuation to the Chennai office, whereby the bank moved the work outside its headquarters in Washington, DC for the first time in its history. The size of the bank's commercial bonds portfolio is estimated at US$100 billion.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = World Bank may ramp up Chennai BPO operations | newspaper = Business Standard | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = Business Standard | date = 17 November 2003 | url = http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/world-bank-may-rampchennai-bpo-operations/161012/ | accessdate = 10 Oct 2012}} On 22 September 2006, the bank moved to a leased premises in [[Taramani]], which was inaugurated by the then chief minister of Tamil Nadu, [[M. Karunanidhi]]. In 2009, the bank decided to purchase the land it took on lease, in order to set up a permanent back office in Chennai. By 2012, the staff strength grew to 500.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = World Bank chief in Chennai | newspaper = Business Line | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = The Hindu | date = 29 March 2012 | url = http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/article3258901.ece | accessdate = 9 Oct 2012}}{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = World Bank chief visits Chennai office | newspaper = ZeeNews India.com | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = ZeeNews.com | date = 29 March 2012 | url = http://zeenews.india.com/business/news/economy/world-bank-chief-visits-chennai-office_44889.html | accessdate = 9 Oct 2012}} The staff growth of the Chennai office is as follows: {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 90%" |- ! Year ! No. of staff |- | 2001 || 80 |- | 2002 || 90 |- | 2003 || 180 |- | 2006 || 240{{cite news | last = PTI | first = | coauthors = | title = World Bank's office opens in Chennai | newspaper = The Economic Times | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = The Times Group | date = 22 September 2006 | url = http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2006-09-22/news/27456107_1_world-bank-office-space-bank-vice-president | accessdate = 10 Oct 2012}} |- | 2012 || 500 |} ==Operations== The World Bank Chennai office building is located in [[Taramani]] on a 3.5-acre campus off the [[Rajiv Gandhi Salai|IT corridor]] and has 120,000 sq feet built-up area with a capacity to house about 450 staff members. The building is certified as a LEED Silver building.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = World Bank Earns LEED Gold for Two Office Buildings | work = | publisher = Greening the Blue.org | date = 15 July 2011 | url = http://www.greeningtheblue.org/news/world-bank-earns-leed-gold-two-office-buildings | format = | doi = | accessdate = 10 Oct 2012}} The Taramani office, measuring 128,000 sq ft area, is the largest bank-owned building outside its headquarters in Washington, DC.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = World Bank Group President thanks Chennai staff for delivering results on the ground | work = World Bank—News & Views | publisher = The World Bank | date = 29 March 2012 | url = http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/2012/03/29/world-bank-group-president-thanks-chennai-staff-for-delivering-results-on-the-ground | format = | doi = | accessdate = 9 Oct 2012}}{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = World Bank chief makes maiden visit to Chennai | newspaper = Business Standard | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = Business Standard | date = 31 March 2012 | url = http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/world-bank-chief-makes-maiden-visit-to-chennai/469599/ | accessdate = 9 Oct 2012}} Most of the administrative expense and trust fund transactions for the Bank, which range between US$1 billion and US$2 billion a year, are processed in the Chennai office. When the bank commenced its Chennai operations, it was primarily restricted to processing. An analysis component was added later.{{cite news | last = Radhakrishnan | first = R. K. | coauthors = | title = World Bank to expand Chennai operations | newspaper = The Hindu | location = Chennai | pages = | language = | publisher = The Hindu | date = 16 November 2003 | url = http://www.hindu.com/2003/11/16/stories/2003111606200100.htm | accessdate = 9 Oct 2012}} ==See also== {{Portal|Chennai}} * [[Economy of Chennai]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.worldbank.org/ Official website] {{Chennai Topics}} {{World Bank}} [[Category:Carbon finance]] [[Category:International economic organizations]] [[Category:United Nations Development Group]] [[Category:World Bank]]

{{Orphan|date=July 2013}}
A '''ZubaBox''' is a [[solar-power]]ed [[Internet cafe|internet café]] developed by [[Computer Aid International]]. It is constructed from used shipping containers and consists of a [[Pentium 4]] PC (3 GHz+, 3GB RAM, 80GB+ HDD), 11 sets of peripherals (keyboards, mice, monitors), 2 desktop virtualisation cards, a ventilation fan for the server, low-power lights and an advanced [[power inverter]].<ref>[http://www.energymatters.com.au/index.php?main_page=news_article&article_id=1958 "Solar Shipping Containers Help Bring Internet to Rural Africa"], ''Energy Matters''</ref> The [[solar panels]] used are poly-crystalline and the cell batteries are of Advanced Glass Mat type. It is named after the [[Nyanja]] word "Zuba", which means "Sun".<ref>[http://www.computeraid.org/zubaBox-solar-internet-hub.asp "ZubaBox Solar Internet Hub"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318043455/http://www.computeraid.org/zubaBox-solar-internet-hub.asp |date=March 18, 2013 }}, ''Computer Aid International''</ref>
== Deployments ==
=== First Deployment ===
The first ever ZubaBox was deployed in a mission hospital in the village of [[Macha, Zambia]] and is used by the [[Johns Hopkins]] Malaria Research Institute. It is located 70 km from the nearest paved road and supports a mesh network with a radius of 1.5 km. The ZubaBox in Macha has a rota system which enables students to use it in the mornings, teachers and nurses to use it for professional training in the afternoon and is then open to adults to use thereafter.<ref>[http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Solar-powered-Internet-cafes-link-rural-Africa/-/1248928/1195700/-/item/0/-/5o0q7c/-/index.html "Solar-powered Internet cafés link rural Africa to global village"], ''Business Daily Africa'', 7 July 2011</ref>
=== Subsequent Deployments ===
Since then, there have been around 10 ZubaBoxes deployed in countries such as [[Nigeria]],<ref>[http://www.onwindows.com/Articles/Dell-launches-ZubaBox-in-Nigeria/7874/Default.aspx "Dell launches ZubaBox in Nigeria"], ''On Windows'', 30 May 2013</ref> [[Zambia]], [[Zimbabwe]]<ref>[https://www.tmcnet.com/usubmit/2012/02/07/6102443.htm "Ensoft And Computer Aid Provide Three ZubaBoxes To Rural Zambia, Zimbabwe And Nigeria"], ''Culture Odyssey''</ref> and [[Kenya]].<ref>[http://www.vertatique.com/containerbased-ict-developing-countries "Container-Based ICT For Developing Countries"], ''Vertatique''</ref>
